reviewText:
-Quick Review-
The Swapper is a Puzzle exploration game, the puzzles start out very dynamic and if you play too late at night (like I did just the last two evenings) they can easily become super challenging. As a whole, I really enjoyed playing this game. The story was quite engaging and interesting.
-Detailed breakdown review-
Story:  The first thing that happens when you load The Swapper is you type out your name. The reason I say that is because I was never directly referred too throughout the game, it was mostly phrases like “hey you, guy who’s doing all these puzzles, go do this for me, because I’m lazy…but I am a girl and have a British accent so naturally you’ll forgive me.”
As you progress through the game you can get more detailed by reading through various logs left throughout the game, however as soon as my screen filled with text I said out loud “too many words!” and skipped and left it. (I sometimes wonder if that’s what people think when they see my reviews…)

Game Play: I’m tempted to compare this game to portal, although instead of thinking with portals you’re thinking with clones. So maybe Naruto meets Portal? You need to shadow clone jutsu yourself through different gravity, various colored lights, and on top of pressure plates to solve the puzzles.

Achievements: The only achievements for this game were hidden information logs that you need to go searching for. It was nice to play a game that didn’t have me do the same type of achievement the whole game. (I.e. finish the game, kill X amount of things, beat the game perfectly, beat hard mode, and then unlock all the special biscuits.)

Price: The Swapper’s standard price is $14.99, I played only 3 hours of the game and beat it. I did need help on three or four puzzles, however even if I just stared at the screen for a few extra hours helplessly lost trying to solve a puzzle, I still wouldn’t have been able to put in more than 10 hours for this game.
I ended up purchasing this game in a humble bundle, (or maybe it was 90% off in a Christmas/summer sale, I can’t remember to be honest) while the game play is enjoyable and the controls are solid, the price is much higher then I’d be willing to purchase at full price.

Conclusion: The story was good, the game play was dynamic and interesting, the achievements were refreshing, but the price was $5.00 too high, I think this game does deserve a play through, if you enjoy puzzle games to any degree I recommend this game.

reviewText:
The Swapper is a side-scrolling puzzle platformer in which you solve puzzles by making clones of yourself. The game has you stranded on a spacestation. Within the game there are many rooms to explore, collecting orbs as you do so. These orbs help you get further in the game. Not that original but it works.

To collect the orbs you have to swap to the clone that is going to be in contact with the orbs. All the clones follow the same movement commands as the main clone. The puzzles mostly consist of rooms where there are special lights where you are unable to spawn a clone, swap to a clone or both. This may sound like a small thing, but the developers really thought about the many ways to use this.

From my experience with the puzzles, some are done in the first try others can take a while.
Often you will find out you just had to do one small trick to progress. The puzzle difficulty gets harder as you go, sometimes with large steps of difficulty. The last levels were really hard (But that could be down to me having a break from the game for a while).

The atmosphere of the game is really well done with the level design, story and sound design all contributing. What made the level design nice was that the whole world was made by using clay and other real objects as background. The world had a nice metroid feel, because you could explore many parts of the world. The only sad thing that later in the game it more felt like going from puzzle room through puzzle room. Happily enough you don't have to solve the puzzles in chronological order even though you still have to finish them all to go to the next area. The only complaint I can give is that some rooms looked the same, due to the dark look. But I guess that also does help with the lost spacestation feel.

The story is mostly told through cutscenes and optional reading messages. What is nice about the story is that it asks philosophical questions to make you think. One thing that can be annoying is that there are rocks in the game that when you pass them, your screen gets blurry and text will pop up. This is okay the first time, but becomes annoying after a while, especially if you have to pass by the same rock several times.  Another thing I found annoying was that some cutscenes aren't skippable so you have to watch them again should you die.

The game took me around 8 hours to complete and the last critical thing I have to say is that there is not much replay value once completed. There are multiple endings, but no reason to play the game all over again except if you wish to. You may be better off just watching the other ending on youtube. The achievements are pretty unfair in the game. I collected them in my first playthrough using a guide and I often thought 'How could anybody find this!?'

There are maybe parts that I am critical about, but they don't hold up in the end with the total experience you get.

reviewText:
I personally hate puzzle games, because I'm not all that smart and I usually end up looking for guides. Don't judge me.

The Swapper is a 2-D puzzle game, one of those games where you advance from room to room and try to solve a puzzle, from easy ones, to absolutely head shattering ones. Kinda like Limbo, but a bit more complex and less about lightning reflexes, IMO.

But the sense of isolation, the atmosphere, the plot, and all in all, the gameplay of this game is just absolutely mind blowing. It's quite challenging, too, the visuals are gorgeous and there's lots to explore if you want to find the secret achievements, too. If you love puzzle games, this is a MUST buy. If you don't, like me, I'd still recommend it. The overall experience was quite delightful.

reviewText:
It took all of four minutes for me to lose my humanity.

The Swapper poses an interesting question, to the tune of several flash games from nearly a decade ago:
What if I give you this device that allows you to duplicate yourself, and shift control between the bodies?

It starts off simple enough, and the title is a dead giveaway. As a game that crystallised into my inventory at random - no doubt due to a bundle - I went in blind, not having the faintest clue as to what it was. The name sounded intriguing, and that's about all the research that was done before hitting the install button.

What followed was an interesting and eerie landscape where you find yourself launched from a spaceship into a barren world, with no means to defend yourself. In this sense, it is very similar to Limbo, but as you progress it becomes more of a Metroid environment than anything else, sans hostile lifeforms.
Not that it will make you feel safe, however.

As you go through the barren planet and the spaceship, meeting with a fellow colonist who must surely have gone mad, and you encounter the only other sentience willing to talk to you, you're in for a trip. You'll find yourself creating clones high above ground level, transferring your conscience to them, and repeating this until you have reached the ungodly height an exit is stationed at, hearing the dull cracks of your lifeless brethren smack into the steel floors below.

Hell, even the first puzzle starts with you essentially killing yourself to escape.

Make no mistake, this is a very fun game, and I might read into it far more than is needed, but there's something in the delivery, the atmosphere reminiscent of Dark Souls, ICO, Metroid and the upcoming Ghost Song, that make for a feeling of utter sadness every time you complete a puzzle and can carry on in the story. It feels like a loss of humanity as you shed coil after mortal coil in the pursuit of answers.

Answers as to what happened to the spaceship and its colonists. Answers as to what it was that murdered everyone. Answers as to where this technology came from.
And knowing it all along.

reviewText:
The Swapper is a mind bender of the third degree. From the opening scene it never discloses more than it wants to, instead forcing you to largely draw your own conclusions as to what transpires. It's an intelligent and brilliantly executed sci-fi narrative that doesn't bombard you with exposition, or easy explanations, culminating in an ending that left me completely stunned. This is a game that wants to make you think, asking questions of morality and withholding the answers, which in the end are entirely yours to decide.

Gameplay is just as smart as the story, and does so without a needlessly large amount of devices or mechanics. The Swapper refers to a device that allows you to create mindless copies of yourself to which you can then transfer, or swap, your consciousness to. With this single tool developer Facepalm Games crafts a relentlessly clever series of puzzles, with solutions that are never unfair or obtuse but at the same time demand meticulous thought and execution.

I was continually impressed by how ingenious the puzzles were, leaving me scratching my head only to discover the answer had been staring me in the face. Like Portal the solutions are almost always much harder to come to than actually pulling them off, which is something so few games seem to understand and makes The Swapper that much more notable.

Every aspect of the arresting presentation works to construct a deliberately isolated and atmospheric experience. Thick shadows drape over the environment, with subdued lighting illuminating the stunning, hand molded character models only so much as to show the way forward. Sound effects as well as the soundtrack are used only when necessary, ensuring you are never unintentionally pulled out of the incredibly engrossing world, but only drawn deeper in.

Right from the start though the four hours it took me to complete it, I couldn't put The Swapper down! It combines an ingenious gameplay mechanic with an enthralling, thought provoking narrative more effectively than we often ever see, and does so without confusing the player or pandering to the lowest common denominator. It's one of the best puzzle platformers I've ever played, easily a top contender for my personal 2013 GOTY, and a must play for any fan of science-fiction and puzzle games in general.

reviewText:
Let's start by saying that this is a puzzle game, if you didn't know.

With that out of the way, if a puzzle game is what you're looking for, I recommend this game wholeheartedly. There are two components in this game: the puzzles and the story that drives you to solve them. Or, if you prefer, the story and the puzzles you have to solve in order to progress in the story. Either way, both story and puzzles hold up their end of the bargain.

The story (by Tom Jubert, who was also behind the story in FTL) puts you in a derelict space station with some sentient rocks, a lunatic, dead crew and a gun that allows you to create clones of yourself and transfer your mind onto them if so you choose. The game explores the difficult subject of identity, the ethics of cloning, and what the hell is going on when you transfer your consciousness to one of your clones (John Perry being transfered to his new body in Old Man's War, anybody?). In order to progress in the story you need to hack into some consoles and you'll have to fetch some cryptographic orbs in order to do it. And that's where the puzzles come in.

In order to reach the orbs, you need to carry out a number of steps that involve creating clones in specific places in the room and transfer control to them (only the clone you control can get the orbs). This is complicated by regions in space with blue, red and purple light. You cannot create clones in regions with blue light; you cannot transfer control to clones when there's a region with red light between you and the clone; and you can do neither when there's purple light (blue and red at the same time). Moreover, for every step you take, the clones take it too (they mimic your movements). You have to use your clones to activate platforms that switch off lights or open hatches. Later in the game, a new mechanic is included to introduce a bit more variety and complication to the puzzles, and it consists in switches that change the gravity of the room from downwards to upwards and the other way around.

I have found the puzzles to be very clever and very satisfying. This is the best I've seen since Braid. I have not found them to be excruciatingly difficult, which is good for me. You are not required to have an outstanding mental performance. We are not talking about being able to plot in your head 100 steps ahead. You just have to see" it. Once you get it
date: the sequence takes only a handful of steps. I only got seriously stuck in four of the puzzles
recommended: and I just solved them by going to sleep. The next day
hoursPlayed: with a clear head and a different perspective
voteText: they all went down in a few minutes. All in all it took me six and a half hours to complete
helpfulPercent: and I'm dumb as ♥♥♥♥ for these things.\n\nOther than that
votesHelpful: I loved the atmosphere. The art and the accompanying music really set the mood perfectly.\n\nIn short: if you are into puzzle games
votesTotal: this is a must in my opinion. And even if you are not a fan of the genre but want some food for thought every now and then (that is my case actually)
votesFunny: I think this is the one you should get next. Unless you have not played Braid. In that case go play Braid NOW and then come back to this one."

reviewText:
Presentation
While it might not be clear at first, The Swapper wants to send a message and then leave you to ask the questions, without ever telling you the answers to them. Clearly inspired by space odyssey classic films such as Moon or Solaris, The Swapper puts you in the role of a stranded spaceman seeking a way out of a space station that is undeniably doomed, but bumping into different stories, messages and characters on the way out, and giving you access to the swapper, a weapon designed to create up to four different clones of yourself and allowing you to swap between them. Once that becomes a regular thing, the game pushes ideas such as what happens to the clones that you leave behind or is swapping souls really a reality, planting them in your head so you can start and ask your own questions about mortality and existence and go deeper with the story it wants to tell based on what you are seeking after processing those things through your head on your own. Even with all the messages left behind and the information you get from other survivors or the mysterious rocks, in the end you will still have unanswered questions, but that is part of the mystery, something that might instantly make a sequel something worth looking into in the future. There is no restriction on where to go and what to do, as each puzzle area solved will reward you with a number of orbs that you will later use to perform a certain action and open up a new area, but the order in which you obtain those orbs and where you want to go next is entirely up to you. On the other hand, exploring other areas of the game wishing that you could uncover more things can leave you disappointed as even with all the movement liberty, the game follows a linear pattern and your only concern is getting the amount of orbs shown about the console in order to make your way to the next area and progress the story, and most areas which are not part of a puzzle portion lack the secondary events to make them worth exploring.
Rating: 9

Gameplay
What makes The Swapper a unique game to play is the weapon that gives the game's title, allowing you to create up to four different clones of yourself, reproducing all your movements and allowing you to swap between them. Standing in your way are three different light beams, starting with the red beam that allows you to create clones inside it, but blocks the ability to swap to other clones if the swapper's trajectory goes through that beam, the blue beam that acts exactly the opposite and the purple beam that has both of the downsides. Combining the use of those beams with typical platforming elements such as gaps between platforms or switches results in unique puzzles that feel refreshing, but at the same time intuitive, making practice and trying out different approaches the key to succeeding. Even though you will mostly use your abilities inside the puzzle sections which are always marked on your map, making your way from one chamber to the next one is a challenge all by itself, as you will often have obstacles in your way or be forced to use the reverse gravity portal to reach the other end of the room. The best thing about the Swapper's gameplay however, is that it never feels old or repetitive as it constantly introduces new elements and making puzzles more challenging, but putting the knowledge your earn throughout the game to good use, they still feel clever and intuitive. As refreshing as the puzzles are, there are some concepts such as the zero gravity sections that feel left behind, as there are no puzzles utilizing that concept and the only portion of the game where the idea was used was when you had to move to the other end of the station in order to advance the game. Messages are also an important part of what The Swapper wants to achieve as they will detail the plot further as well as provide hints to help you complete puzzles easier and use the game's mechanics in a better way.
Rating: 8.5

Graphics
This game is merely beautiful, and even though the entire story takes place in and around a space station, the environment is crafted in such a way to make each chamber feel unique and a significant part of the same set of rooms. The design feels monotone, but in this case that only contributes to the overall feeling of being stranded in space, desperately looking for the way out, only to find yourself in another chamber that looks different and at the same time astonishingly beautiful, but putting your skills to the test once more.
Rating: 9.5

Audio
As good as it looks, The Swapper knows exactly the way it wants to make you feel by adding thrilling tunes in the background and changing the tone whenever something significant happens. Apart from the few characters that you will encounter during your journey there is little dialogue, but you will find console messages left behind wherever you go and rocks that will leave you messages that go deeper into the story, but unfortunately those are not voiced over, which is disappointing considering the bigger impact a godly rock leaving you messages could have on the lonely ambient.
Rating: 8.5

Extras
It takes around 6 hours to get through the game's campaign, maybe another extra hour if some puzzles give you a hard time, and even though the ending is more than worth the journey, there is nothing else waiting for you afterwards. There is an alternate ending however, which can only be seen if you replay the entire campaign and take a different choice at the end, but considering the fact that you already know how to solve each puzzle, you'll probably question yourself if a second playthrough is really worth it when you can just look for the alternate ending online.
Rating: 6

Verdict
The Swapper is truly one of a kind experience, and while it comes with its few flaws and ideas not reaching the peek they could have, for the price tag it comes with, it is more than worth the purchase, especially if you're into platformers and looking for something fresh to bring you back into the game.
Rating Overall: 8.3

Check out the full review and a lot more about The Swapper at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=266[/h1]

reviewText:
OH GOD BUY THIS GAME

The puzzles are PERFECT. Difficult, but logical. YOU WILL NEVER NEED A WALKTHROUGH. Each new puzzle is based off previous knowledge, no sudden leaps in difficulty that cause you to get stuck.

I think it's a shame that an otherwise cohesive, beautifully made game included such an obvious trick to try and make the game seem deeper or keep people playing. It's completely unnecessary.

Otherwise though, everything about this game is a fantastic experience. GET IT NOW!

reviewText:
I'm not sure why, but when I first got this game from the Humble Bundle, I wasn't expecting much. Boy did I change my mind quick. This game was an absolute delight, with a thought-provoking story and deep message. This game does a great job of putting you in a lonely and desolate spaceship, and the atmosphere is incredible. The puzzles are classic for a puzzle genre, with switches and different coloured lights which don't exactly turn the puzzle genre on its head or introduce anything new. That aside, the puzzles are an absolute joy and are very satisfactory. My only real issue with this game is that the achievements require you to find hidden rooms with no clues or allusions to where they might be. In a massive ship like this, they can be a pain to find. So if you are an achievement hunter, have a guide on hand.

Pros:
+ Deep and thought-provoking theme
+ Great atmosphere
+ Satisfactory puzzles

Cons:
-Frustrating achievements that are impossible to find without a guide.

Overall, this game is the best I have played in recent years. I recommend this game whole-heartedly.

reviewText:
A side-scrolling puzzle platformer made unique by an interesting game mechanic; the ability to create clones and swap your consciousness to the newly created clone!

As you move around and solve puzzles the bodies of the clones you’ve recently inhabited inevitably meet their end and when they do its impossible not to wonder, was it murder or suicide?

Expect an eerie setting inside a derelict space station, with a low-key pace, and well-designed puzzles that rise in difficulty pleasantly to keep you satisfied all the way until the unnerving finale.

reviewText:
Wow. Just, wow. I just finished the Steam indie game 'The Swapper'. Amazing. Deep. Thought-provoking. Questions of nouemenal and phenomenal basis for knowledge, mortality, consciousness and more form the basis of the deep and 'twisty' (???) story of this game. Clearly very Platonic, Neitzschean, Kantian influenced. The 'end' was 'sufficient' and playing through the game itself was the most rewarding part. The atmosphere and aesthetic reminds me of a mix of 'Alien' and 'Dead Space' and the visuals are absolutely gorgeous (iirc, they were all hand-crafted with clay or something).

It's a 'pure' puzzle-platformer (no combat) that's really, really fun and addictive and at times *absolutely brain-busting*. Loading times are literally non-existant. Gameplay involves your character finding a device that can create mindless 'clones' of yourself that move exactly as you move. You can transfer your 'consciousness' / 'will' to any of them, given that you have a direct line of sight. Sometimes your previous 'selves' must be sacrificed in order to use the environment and this device to accomplish puzzles and progress in the game. Very interesting and innovative gameplay mechanics, here.

Definitely recommend! 9/10, would bang.

reviewText:
Wow. Just, wow. I just finished the Steam indie game 'The Swapper'. Amazing. Deep. Thought-provoking. Questions of nouemenal and phenomenal basis for knowledge, mortality, consciousness and more form the basis of the deep and 'twisty' (???) story of this game. Clearly very Platonic, Neitzschean, Kantian influenced. The 'end' was 'sufficient' and playing through the game itself was the most rewarding part. The atmosphere and aesthetic reminds me of a mix of 'Alien' and 'Dead Space' and the visuals are absolutely gorgeous (iirc, they were all hand-crafted with clay or something).

It's a 'pure' puzzle-platformer (no combat) that's really, really fun and addictive and at times *absolutely brain-busting*. Loading times are literally non-existant. Gameplay involves your character finding a device that can create mindless 'clones' of yourself that move exactly as you move. You can transfer your 'consciousness' / 'will' to any of them, given that you have a direct line of sight. Sometimes your previous 'selves' must be sacrificed in order to use the environment and this device to accomplish puzzles and progress in the game. Very interesting and innovative gameplay mechanics, here.

Definitely recommend! 9/10, would bang.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AidyRHYg74c

reviewText: This is one of those games that really surprised me; honestly I didn't expect much from an indie game. reviewText:
OH GOD BUY THIS GAME

The puzzles are PERFECT. Difficult, but logical. YOU WILL NEVER NEED A WALKTHROUGH. Each new puzzle is based off previous knowledge, no sudden leaps in difficulty that cause you to get stuck.

The story is confusing, but has a very satisfying ending. The themes of the story are fascinating and complement the gameplay nicely.

The only thing about this game I consider a flaw is the inclusion of secret rooms that are extremely difficult to find. Each one gives you an achievement and a bit of backstory, but unless you use a guide you'll probably never find them. I think it's a shame that an otherwise cohesive, beautifully made game included such an obvious trick to try and make the game seem deeper or keep people playing. It's completely unnecessary.

Otherwise though, everything about this game is a fantastic experience. GET IT NOW!

reviewText: True to the Indie genre" (the air quotes are there for a reason)
date: The Swapper is a short but powerful experience - if you have the mental patience to stick with it.\n\nThe gameplay premise is pretty simple to explain. You have a Swapper that can create a maximum of 4 clones which copy your every move
recommended: and allows you to 'swap' with them by shooting them.\nIn your way stand two lights which block clone placement or swapping rays
hoursPlayed: and at times are found combined. Adding in hold-buttons that switch some of these lights or a blocking stone slide
voteText: we also have a gravity mechanic that uses gravity 'pads' to change your vertical gravity and the gravity of your consequently spawned clones.\nYou can easily imagine the complexity of these one-room puzzles

column18:
maybe the rare few feats of speedy thinking (the button to place clones slows time down when held) but in general it's all about figuring out the right order to do things. Trial and Error has helped me through most of the puzzles.

Storywise... It's hard to say anything without spoiling a whole bunch.
Not including the rare few 'cutscenes' from the same side-scrolling perspective
column19: there are three main sources of story in this game. You have Data Terminals which provide some context on the 'missing' crew's experience before and during the main events of the story in shape of reports and written short conversations (presumably 'chats') ; the 'Watchers' in shape of strange boulders that distort your screen and show a few short words ; and speech of the rare occasional NPC walking by at a close but for-now unreachable location.\n\nAll in all
column20: this was a 5-hour trip and has brought up some interesting questions around the identity of 'self' or what we call the 'soul'. Whether it actually answers these... not so much.\nAn interesting experience

reviewText: The Swapper is a great game that plays with concepts from the philosophy of mind, staring Daniel Dennett and David Chalmers discussion over the question of whether consciousness/mind can exist independently of the brain, but this is presented piece by piece, nice and easy. Aside from that, the game has very interesting puzzles: they are somehow straightforward, but not always easy to solve. I recommend it for philosophy and original puzzle lovers. Although it is a platformer, almost no “jumping & running” skills are necessary to play, for which I’m very thankful. It is a delightful experience from the beginning to the end. The fact that it is made out of clay, like The Neverhood and The Dream Machine, is a very nice touch too. This is an all-time favorite.

reviewText:
The Swapper seemed to me on its surface like some kind of subdued indie horror game. Its visuals and presentation piqued my interest.

I was pleasantly surprised to find that its core mechanic was really the star of the show. In a genre so awash with titles that try way too hard to be innovative and not hard enough to actually be a good game, it's refreshing to see a game with genuinely unique gameplay that's genuinely fun to play at its core.

It's short, and the plot isn't all that interesting, but the puzzles are great, swapping is simple but has a wide bredth of uses, and looks gorgeous.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: It's like playing a literally hand-crafted Super Metroid (very often the designs approach 1:1) with enemies swapped for puzzles that stand shoulder to shoulder with Portal. The story, written by one of the minds behind Penumbra, is just as equally well crafted as the gameplay. If the sentence Super Metroid  with a unique puzzle twist and a well written space-horror plot." even remotely perks your interest get The Swapper."
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Finished this game in two sittings. Including 100% achievements. I'm not saying it's short, it's me not able to resist playing it. Graphics, music, audio are making a great and deep environment.

Achievements, which are logs located in well-hidden secret rooms, are super hard to find. I found one by pure accident. I was nearly at the end of the game already, so I used a guide to find the others.

This game also has two interesting endings. Unfortunately, if you don't think it up beforehand, once you reach one of the endings it will rewrite your save file with a spot that loads ending credits, so you will have to play through entire game again. I suggest you to make a copy of your game profile just before you make final decision. Or ask me if you need a save.

I loved this game for its puzzles, easy pace, graphic and sound design, for giving me creepy and mystic feeling, for atmosphere.
I wish there were more games like this.

reviewText: Great puzzle-platformer. It's basically a cross between Portal and Metroidvania games with some very challenging puzzles to solve. But what absolutely sells this game is the aesthetic and atmosphere. It's a game where all the assets are hand-made, mostly of clay and it looks just gorgeous, along with the great environment and lighting effects. I think however that $15 is a bit much for 4.5 hours, and I'm not the sharpest tool in the shed so I assume people have beaten it quicker than me. And it doesn't really provide any replay value. Granted, I paid about $0.50 for it when I bought the Humble Bundle and for that it's absolutely amazing, but I'd say wait for a sale. Much of the puzzle design is in line with what you can find on the better flash games on newgrounds, but the atmosphere is well worth a purchase.\n

reviewText:
I'm not sure why, but when I first got this game from the Humble Bundle, I wasn't expecting much. Boy did I change my mind quick. This game was an absolute delight, with a thought-provoking story and deep message. This game does a great job of putting you in a lonely and desolate spaceship, and the atmosphere is incredible. The puzzles are classic for a puzzle genre, with switches and different coloured lights which don't exactly turn the puzzle genre on its head or introduce anything new. That aside, the puzzles are an absolute joy and are very satisfactory. My only real issue with this game is that the achievements require you to find hidden rooms with no clues or allusions to where they might be. In a massive ship like this, they can be a pain to find. So if you are an achievement hunter, have a guide on hand.

Pros:
+ Deep and thought-provoking theme
+ Great atmosphere
+ Satisfactory puzzles

Cons:
-Frustrating achievements that are impossible to find without a guide.

Overall, this game is the best I have played in recent years. I recommend this game whole-heartedly.

reviewText:
A side-scrolling puzzle platformer made unique by an interesting game mechanic; the ability to create clones and swap your consciousness to the newly created clone!

As you move around and solve puzzles the bodies of the clones you’ve recently inhabited inevitably meet their end and when they do its impossible not to wonder, was it murder or suicide?

Expect an eerie setting inside a derelict space station, with a low-key pace, and well-designed puzzles that rise in difficulty pleasantly to keep you satisfied all the way until the unnerving finale.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is a really good platformer.   The puzzles are unique, the game has challenge and keeps your interest.  The graphics and environment set well for the games atomosphere.   I'm enjoying this game immensly, it's different, it's intriguing and it keeps your mind thinking on how to solve puzzles.   I like how it uses color and beams to determine what functions your character can use.    The type of beams determine what you can and cannot do if your character crosses them.   You can create duplicates of yourself as part of the puzzle solving process and it's required.    The game leads you into the abilities of your character so it doesn't seem as if poof" you can do these neat abilities it was a gradual process of instruduction being able to create mujltiple entities of yourself and swap with them to solve a puzzle.   I didn't find any bugs either.    If your looking for constant action packed excitement don't look here this one is for those who enjoy a unique twist to puzzle solving and does very well at it.   IF you like puzzle solving which is very rewarding look no futher this one will keep your attention for many hours and get you hooked and become a Swapper fan.  I look forward to seeing additional Swapper titles as this type of game can go really far and the story is great.     I hope the developer makes more I can't wait to see what they can do by expanding a very impressive concept.   There's nothing like it pick this gem up.\n\nDisclaimer:  Although it says 1 hour on record this appears to be incorrect.  Many hours have been played so this is somewhat confusing as the game time is wrong.   I have indeed played it for more than 3 hours and intend to do more until I reach the end."

reviewText: Great puzzle-platformer. It's basically a cross between Portal and Metroidvania games with some very challenging puzzles to solve. But what absolutely sells this game is the aesthetic and atmosphere. It's a game where all the assets are hand-made, mostly of clay and it looks just gorgeous, along with the great environment and lighting effects. I think however that $15 is a bit much for 4.5 hours, and I'm not the sharpest tool in the shed so I assume people have beaten it quicker than me. And it doesn't really provide any replay value. Granted, I paid about $0.50 for it when I bought the Humble Bundle and for that it's absolutely amazing, but I'd say wait for a sale. Much of the puzzle design is in line with what you can find on the better flash games on newgrounds, but the atmosphere is well worth a purchase.\n

reviewText:
A side-scrolling puzzle platformer made unique by an interesting game mechanic; the ability to create clones and swap your consciousness to the newly created clone!

As you move around and solve puzzles the bodies of the clones you’ve recently inhabited inevitably meet their end and when they do its impossible not to wonder, was it murder or suicide?

Expect an eerie setting inside a derelict space station, with a low-key pace, and well-designed puzzles that rise in difficulty pleasantly to keep you satisfied all the way until the unnerving finale.

reviewText:
The Swapper is a rather simple puzzle platformer with an interesting gameplay: you are equipped with a unique weapon which allows you to create clones of yourself and swap with them. Confusing? I just may lack words to actually describe it correctly, but it really is a simple concept and will take you no more than 2 minutes to get used to what you need to do.

There's no one to kill in this game, there are no quick movements (mostly) so that kind of skill is far from needed. What you really need is a brain and some patience in order to complete this game. Mind you, it's not really a brain-killer as most puzzles are really easy to complete. Sometimes all you need is a two minute break to rest a bit and it will all come to you.

Anyway, what's it about? You are an astronaut on a Space Station Theseus and there's been an accident. You are trying to escape as well as find out what actually happened there. In order to progress you need to open certain doors and each door requires you to own a certain number of orbs. Orbs can be collected by solving puzzles. To solve puzzles you need to create clones of yourself (and swap places with your own clones, as I said before). These clones will do exactly the same movements and actions as yourself and you will need to use them to open doors, step on certain spots etc.

As I said, the game is incredibly simple in its mechanics, but is challenging enough to keep you playing it for 5 or 6 hours until the very end. I really enjoyed the time spent on this and I managed to get stuck only once! And it was only because I didn't notice one floor tile (it was upside down and I guess I was just too tired). The real challenges come up at later stages as you get into rooms where you know exactly what you need to do - but you need to figure HOW to do it.

One real good feature are teleporters that will allow you to move quickly if you ever need to go back to some room (if you missed something or took a left turn and now you want to go right). I just love it when developers think about us players and our need to cut down the lost time :)

There are 10 achievements in the game as well and they are real pain in the ♥♥♥. Not because they are too hard to get or are luck based... No, it's because they require you to find 10 hidden rooms and to do that you would need to randomly clone and swap yourself into hidden walls and corridors. Most of the time such corridors are too well hidden and you'd do better if you ignore that part of the game completely. Unless you read a guide or watch YouTube videos to find out their locations.

Overall, The Swapper is a beautiful and entertaining indie game that will leave you asking for more. As for the actual story that develops as you progress - I leave that to you. It's a bit confusing... and unimportant, to be honest. Enjoy it while it lasts.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm not sure why, but when I first got this game from the Humble Bundle, I wasn't expecting much. Boy did I change my mind quick. This game was an absolute delight, with a thought-provoking story and deep message. This game does a great job of putting you in a lonely and desolate spaceship, and the atmosphere is incredible. The puzzles are classic for a puzzle genre, with switches and different coloured lights which don't exactly turn the puzzle genre on its head or introduce anything new. That aside, the puzzles are an absolute joy and are very satisfactory. My only real issue with this game is that the achievements require you to find hidden rooms with no clues or allusions to where they might be. In a massive ship like this, they can be a pain to find. So if you are an achievement hunter, have a guide on hand.

Pros:
+ Deep and thought-provoking theme
+ Great atmosphere
+ Satisfactory puzzles

Cons:
-Frustrating achievements that are impossible to find without a guide.

Overall, this game is the best I have played in recent years. I recommend this game whole-heartedly.

reviewText: Привлечь мое внимание к компьютерной игре довольно просто: нужно лишь пообещать, что она рассказывает о космосе и одиночестве. А можно даже и этого не делать; достаточно поместить на обложку фигурку астронавта. Именно поэтому я купила в свое время на распродаже The Swapper.\n\nИ вот что я скажу: заброшенные космические станции, археологические раскопки на иных планетах, загадочные артефакты, мозги в банках, клоны, таинственная и выкосившая экипаж напасть, мыслящая неорганика, сомнительные эксперименты, — все это, конечно, «уже было» и еще не раз будет. Из этих переменных можно сложить равно эпический блокбастер и третьесортный хоррор, но нужно обладать недюжинным талантом и прекрасным чувством меры, чтобы буквально на коленке слепить из них — а также из глины (!) — философскую притчу, в которой, как и в космосе, нет ничего лишнего, и все на своих местах.

reviewText:
Decent indie puzzler, not an amazing find like Limbo or Braid, not as much variety as Fez, but still worth the asking price. Relatively short, but I didn't mind. Good for one playthrough.

Most people rave about the visuals assembled from digitized clay sculpture, but I found the amount of bloom and distortion effects applied to be mildly aggravating, like an almost unnoticed headache.

Replayability is nil unless you're an achievement completionist. There's a binary moral choice at the end which requires an entire replay just to see the alternative. No thanks, I'll just watch a replay.

the novelty of the swapper mechanic with its challenging puzzles makes up for its faults. The voice acting is good. The story is decent; not as profound as I imagine the creators hoped, but not preachy or pretentious. The music is nice and, if you're like most people who like the visuals, complements the atmosphere.

reviewText:
The quick review - LIMBO meets Portal 2 with a dash of Dead Space - combine those games with a stunning soundtrack so crisp you would be forgiven for wanting to climb into your monitor 'Ring' style to experience the atmosphere first hand along with the lone astronaut. * * * * *
Want more?
The game is that kind of simple that makes other games like LIMBO charismatic rather than laborious, I won’t forget the first time I played LIMBO and pulled the boat up the shore to reach a higher level, this game captures that nice feel and almost instantly I felt a connection with the person in the space suit.
You have a gun that clones your character up to four time and you use this and a few stylish techniques to navigate the beautiful and uncomplicated surroundings. I’m about 11 hours into the game now and unlike some games I haven’t needed to scan the internet to find the answer to a puzzle; the game explains itself in a simple yet effective way. The computer systems in the game tell a story as well as a former astronaut who we hear in flashback I presume (I haven’t yet completed the game) finally when you pass some of the planets mined rocks they seem to send messages to you as well which brings in the Dead Space element to the game!
Buy this game for your friends in the sale if you want to spend a little less but honestly you won’t regret it and you friends will thank you for it.

This is one of those games were you want a t-shirt and comic book series spin off. Roll on the dates where the game is ported to consoles.

This game gets five stars from me, for what that’s worth.

I just finished this game and WOW, was it amazing. reviewText:
Well... was so good I just sat there and finished it in one go.

Really good puzzle platformer, a sort of mix between LIMBO and portal, but longer than both (took me 5 hours).

The cloning / swapping mechanism - which the whole game is based on - is unlocked from the start, and simple to learn, but the difficulty ramps up rather fast and you find yourself often forced to think outside the box.

The difficulty was challenging but just about right. You can skip some rooms and revisit them later (once you've done the last rooms, they will seem easy!). A couple of time I almost felt the temptation to youtube some solutions, but thankfully I resisted the urge and forced myself to think all the way!

A pure pleasure; one of those few game that make you feel you became smarter after you played them.

Oh and I almost forgot to mention, the art is beautiful and the story well thought provoking.

reviewText:
There are few games that ask the player to answer questions it raises, and even fewer that employ game-mechanics so focused on the narrative. The Swapper succeeds in the former category, but the latter feels not often thought out.

Don't let what I've said turn you away. Sure, it's an artsy kind of platformer with a philosophical undertone, but the story is captivating to unravel for yourself and the gameplay is superb as well to make playing the game equally as challenging.

What Makes It So Special?
Unlike many artsy-smartsy platformers with almost zero mechanics, The Swapper will warrant you to play the game for its challenge as a puzzle game. It's undoubtly a game.

In the Swapper, you have the ability to create copies of yourself and to transfer your soul" to another clone. The game will slow down and you can place your clones with your mouse or right-thumbstick. This comes into play when you have more quick-reaction puzzles.

Sounds simple

reviewText:
The Swapper is an atmospheric 2D puzzle game which takes place on a mostly-deserted space station.  The puzzles primarily consist of making clones of your character (which jump and move in unison with you) and then “swapping” your current self with one of your clones.  While the story is a bit abstract, the puzzles are expertly crafted and strike the right balance of difficulty and creativity.

In the Swapper, you play an astronaut who is exploring a mostly-empty space station.  It is quickly revealed that the inhabitants of the station found a unique type of rock species which contains a shared conscience.  The rocks are seemingly benign, but as you solve puzzles and make progress deeper into the story, more is revealed on the nature of the rocks and of the researchers.  By the end, Swapper asks a lot of deep questions about conscience, the soul, and existence.  Some of it is genuinely intriguing and thought-provoking, but I would be lying if I said some of it didn’t go a bit over my head.

One thing is for certain: the Swapper absolutely oozes atmosphere.  The vastness and emptiness of the space station which you are exploring is really incredible; a top-notch music soundtrack and the claymation graphics certainly help.

Of course, the puzzles themselves in the Swapper are truly the star of the game.  At the beginning of the game, puzzles are relatively straight-forward but are still interesting and creative.  By the end, more mechanics are introduced and there are some puzzles which I found quite difficult -- one in particular had me walk away for a bit and I literally thought of the solution while taking a shower.  Most importantly, all of the puzzles in the Swapper never feel like they are cheating you; the solution always feels on the tip of your fingers and, once you reach it, is always extremely satisfying.

Anyone who hasn’t played the Swapper and loves puzzle games, especially along the lines of Portal, should absolutely play this game.  The story is interesting (if not a bit confusing), the puzzles are excellent, and it’s all accented with excellent music and graphics.  It’s a short experience, but definitely one worth the price of entry.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Alright, I've been playing this for about three hours now. I definitely am enjoying this game. The setting, the atmosphere, the sobering graphics....they are all top notch. The 2-D scrolling with lush backgrounds works quite well (this is much the same as Deadlight as far as the way in which the background is presented as something vibrant but untouchable).
So, the gameplay is pretty straight forward, but the difficulty definitely spikes after about an hour, and at the point I'm at now, some of the puzzles seem near impossible. This isnt a bad thing, and I know there is a solution for all of them, but they really get incredibly challenging in my opinion.
Speaking of gameplay, it's a simple affair. A and D to move around, W or space to jump, E to activate objects, S to hold movable objects. The mouse is used to adjust view, project and swap your clones. All your clones move together, and you can have a total of four out there at any time.
The puzzles themselves are mostly color oriented with pressure plates, deadfalls, jumps, etc...entering into the mix.
There are also a couple zero gravity sections where you have to adjust your gameplay a bit.
Anyway, this is definitely a fun, intense game well worth trying out.

Now, a couple SPOILERS....SPOILERS....SPOILERS

When you are projecting your clone, the game slows down to a crawl. You can use this to help slow your falls and time your swaps while falling, which you will need to do. You can also use swapping to basically climb through the air.

The story has taken on a touch of sci-fi horror at the point I'm at. I've uncovered about 2/3 of the map so far, and I imagine the story will get a bit darker as it continues. There are weird, seemingl;y intelligent stones throughout the complex. They all have a thought stored in them. I am guessing that as people were experimenting with the swapping devices initially, their thoughts/memories were transfered to the stones, and possibly their bodies were possessed by the minds of the alien stones. This is strictly specualtion on my part right now though, but I thought it would be fun to see if I was correct or not.

Achievements; These have nothing to do with gameplay, the story, or anything else. They are each linked to hidden messages found throughout the game. You cant see where they are and the means to get to them is never obvious (they are in blacked out sections that dont look like you can actually access). I havent actually found any, but I just watched a video on them and realized I missed 6 or 7 of them already.


SPOILERS END HERE

All in all, TL:DR, but enjoy regardless.

reviewText:
What a game. Everything about The Swapper is awesome.

GRAPHICS: The Swapper could have easily contented itself with some cheap cartoon or 8-bit art style. Thankfully, The devs went all out in the graphics department, crafting detailed art assets out of clay to convey its world. The game is technically 2D, but uses adavanced Depth of Field and lighting effects to convincingly simulate environments, in a very atmospheric way. It's one of the best looking games I've ever seen, indie or otherwise.

SOUND/MUSIC: The game also has solid sound design. Reverb is very well done and does wonders in terms of selling the atmosphere. Every sound is high quality and properly processed for where the sound occurs (in a hallway, in airlock, etc). The soundtrack is great as well: solemn tunes ranging from classical-ish piano pieces to atmospheric electronic tones.

GAMEPLAY: Movement and mouse control are very polished, as is the Swapper mechanic. Basically, you can create up to four clones of yourself anywhere on-screen that is not blocked, and they mirror your movemnts. You can then swap to become any one of them with the device. The great depth of this mechanic is revealed as you progress through the game, introducing pressure pads, lights that block certain functions of the device, and much more. Solving puzzles rewards you with one or more orbs" that allow you to activate consoles to progress. This is balanced so that you can skip some puzzles and still progress
date: though you have to complete all puzzles to reach the game's ending (you can use teleport devices to re-visit earlier puzzles). I had to consult a walkthrough twice towards the end of the game
recommended: but in general the puzzles were balanced
voteText: and very well designed.\n\nSTORY: Pay close attention from the very beginning to the very end
helpfulPercent: and play in large chunks of time. You don't want to miss a single detail in The Swapper's incredible story. Without spoiling anything
votesHelpful:
the plot is directly linked to the core gameplay mechanics in a very unique way. I will never forget the ending.

VERDICT: 9.5/10
Would clone myself so I could recommend it more
Would swap myself so I could experience it again"

reviewText:
The Swapper is undoubtedly a puzzle game inspired by Portal. But is it just another ♥♥♥♥♥♥ clone, or maybe something else? Let's find out.

The game is set on some kind of abandoned space station orbiting an unexplored planet, where our main character arrives at the beginning. We don't know who he is or why is he there. Soon we'll find the Swapper, a portal-gun-like device that will become our main tool throughout the game.

It has two functions: creating a clone of yourself at a certain location that will move exactly as you and swapping the control from yourself to the clone. You can have up to four clones plus the main character at the same time. With such a powerful tool, you would think no puzzle will resist you more than a few seconds. And here it comes the brilliance of the game designers: the puzzles ARE hard. The start being easy, but soon you will find yourself stuck for the first time.

Fortunately, the game offers the player some freedom on the order puzzles must be done (but eventually every one must be completed to end the game), so you don't desperately stand for hours trying the same puzzle. Also, it alternates these puzzles with more narrative sequences, letting you learn some of what happened here before your arrival. The story itself is quite interesting, following the path of speculative / philosophical science-fiction, and has a really decent ending.

On the art of the game, the graphics are nice and original, specially textures, through the character moves seem quite orthopedic and sometimes there is just too much blur on the screen. On the other hand, the soundrack is outstanding, ranging from ambient passages that get you into the isolation atmosphere of the game to beautiful and evocative piano melodies.

In conclusion, The Swapper is an awesome adventure and a very well done game in every aspect of its development. It is however a bit expensive for the 5/6 hours that last a basic gameplay. But hey, it is on sale quite often.

reviewText:
The “artistic” puzzle/exploration game with strong philosophical undertones seems trendy of late. Especially with all these indie developers vying to be the one to finally get games recognized as “art”. But as Facepalm Games seems to understand, art isn’t about the destination. It’s about what brought you there.

The Swapper does not lack for artistic content. All of the visuals are made from clay models and other real-world materials, given a fancy shader to make your unnamed spaceman’s flashlight bounce off their surfaces realistically. It’s beautiful in its simplicity and effectiveness, invoking a mood very reminiscent of the cult-classic 1972 sci-fi movie Silent Running.

The Mr. Spaceman you play, comes across a strange device that lets you create clones and swap between them. All the clones mimic your movements exactly. The first time you get so caught up in solving a puzzle that you forget which one was “you” (which you then accidentally kill), is a very memorable moment. If a clone dies, it’s no big deal. You just make another. But there’s only one of you. Right?

The puzzles get tricky, but frustration is offset due to the open-world nature of the space station. While you are gated somewhat, multiple puzzles are available to you at any time. Exploration leads to discovery, and clues about the strange sentient rocks everywhere in the station.

reviewText:
Come for the puzzles & stay for the story. The Swapper is a puzzler in the strictest sense.

Let's be honest; if you've played games long enough, you've come to realize that all games are essentially puzzles. Some are more satisfying than others. The Swapper delivers great puzzles but does so with a riveting story entrenched in an atmospheric thriller. I was kept on my seat wondering what the heck was going to happen next and was continually satiated by having to solve rewarding puzzles. They are rewarding in the sense that many of them are by no means easy. Put your thinking cap on, folks.

I can’t imagine a gamer not enjoying the experience of The Swapper. Grab it in a bundle, on sale, on a flying raccoon; just make sure you grab it somewhere!

One thing of note is that the achievements are a bit wonky. I didn’t realize this on my first play through so I didn’t get credit for them. Make sure you select Beta Compatibility mode. Library > The Swapper > Properties > Betas > Compatibility. Enjoy!

reviewText:
The swapper is an experience you will remember for a long time.

Pros: The puzzles are great and tricky and when you get the solution you don't feel cheated. None are too hard to make you frustrated. The atmosphere of the game is something you will remember. The sound, the lighting, the different areas of the ship, the space travel... there are moments that will just leave you stunned.

Cons: Not much but if I had to point out a couple then firstly, the achievement system is designed to make you play through the game again. You won't get any achievements unless you are actively looking for them because they need you to access hidden rooms which are really well hidden :). Secondly, the story, though great, is not told directly in the game. You need to make sense out of the various dialogues and it will leave you thinking about what is happening through out the game.

Overall, it is a great game in my opinion and I would highly recommend everyone to experience this.

reviewText:
The Swapper is a sci-fi'ish sidescrolling puzzle platformer set on a space station far away from any civilization or help and utilizes a fairly unique puzzle mechanic where you use your Swapping device to create clones of yourself which will act and move the same way you do and will help you solve the numerous puzzles in the game to collect Orbs with which you can unlock further areas of the space station.

Without spoiling too much, the story isn't anything groundbreaking or innovative, but it's told in a fairly interesting manner and keeps you going. With the overall theme of the game, it actually proves to be quite deep if you pay attention and take the time to think about it for a bit.

As mentioned before, the main puzzle mechanic of the game is to create clones of yourself which move simultaneously with you and which you have to place in the right spots to trigger switches and so on. Additionally, you can freely switch between all created clones and take control of them so they become the 'main character', which is especially useful with puzzles where you tend to die.

Dying is actually a large part of the puzzle experience as you will have to first figure out how the puzzle is supposed to work before you actually solve it and that will definitely produce some, uh, collateral damage. Luckily enough, only your main character can actually die, which will cause you to respawn in the room you're currently in.

To add a bit of challenge to it, there are red, blue and purple lights placed in the enviroments, which will prevent you from either creating clones or swapping between them - or both. Around halfway through the game, another puzzle mechanic is introduced where you have glowing platforms on the ground and/or ceiling, that will alter gravity and basically flip you upside-down (similar to VVVVVV), which adds another tad of challenge to the puzzles.

Personally, and despite the above mentioned challenge mechanics, I found the puzzles to be fairly simple and relatively easy for the most part. There definitely were some tough nuts among them, but unfortunately those were the exception to the rule.

Visually, the game looks fairly cool and gets even cooler once you realize that all of what you see there 'is constructed using clay models and other everyday materials'. The lighting, depth of field and bloom also add a lot to the atmosphere of the enviroments, though I would've wished for a slightly brighter level design as some areas are literally pitch black.

With around 5 hours of playtime, The Swapper isn't overly long but feels just about right for the game. Unfortunately, it doesn't really offer any replay value unless you want to replay it for the sake of paying more attention to the story and dialogues.

As a PSA: If you plan to get the achievements in the game (which require you to find 10 hidden consoles), make sure to do it before you activate the final 124-Orb terminal, as this is a point of no return and you will have to replay the whole game again in case you missed any of the achievements.

All in all, The Swapper is a really impressive debut game of Finnish developer Facepalm Games and I'm definitely looking forward to see more quality games like this from them.

reviewText:
This is a puzzle platformer with a distinct ambient, alone-in-space feeling, that you can play at your own pace.

In the game, you clone yourself and swap your consciousness between those clones, in order to get past obstacles and collect orbs. It has a deep plot line (though there are plot holes here or there), with a decision to eventually make.

Along the way, there are also some secret rooms you can find if you're skilled enough at platformers to know how to look for them. Also, make sure to read up on the controls before playing. This isn't a spoiler at all, but I'll put it in a spoiler tag just in case:  just hold down the 'make clone' button to slow down time. Seriously. Without this, the game is nearly unplayable, but it may not be clear that holding it down slows down time.

As an old fan of Oddworld, I absolutely love this game. The puzzles are challenging, but not impossible, and definitely give you that great 'ah-hah!' feeling when you solve one. As long as you're working the controls correctly, you don't need to be that quick on the keyboard, but you do need to be paying attention during the puzzles to align and time things correctly.

The content isn't graphic, though it may contain some slightly disturbing ideas to sensitive folk. Really though, from what I've seen, you could be 10 and play this game, because none of it is any worse than what you'd see in any Star Wars movie.

It's on sale right at the time of me writing this review, so give it a try!

reviewText: The Swapper is an indie platform/puzzle game with an extraordinarily innovative concept. The main character wields a device that allows you to create clones and swap places with any of the clones, and you have to get to the next point using this swapper device. The levels are very well designed and ordered, so it was very entertaining throughout, and nowhere was it too difficult. Not only is gameplay outstanding, but the setting is also superb. the game takes place in a space station where nearly everyone has died due to an unknown psychological phenomenon. The game has a ominous and eerie tone that successfully binds you to the story and makes you want to find out what is happening as story reveals, and the ending gives you something to think about philosophically. I give this game full recommendation to everyone.

reviewText: Puzzle-based games rarely offer the depth and atmosphere The Swapper provides. The game takes place in a beautifully realized science fiction setting; as you traverse an enormous yet desolate research station orbiting an alien world, you begin to piece together an understanding of the events which led it to such a state. However, with each bit of information about the past that you uncover, new questions about the present begin to appear.\n\nOverall, The Swapper is a game that accomplishes a lot without overstaying its welcome. It's short enough (roughly 3 - 6 hours) that despite puzzle mechanics that are fairly limited in scope, it rarely feels repetitive, and it leaves you satisfied but wanting more. I'd highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Loved this game. The puzzles could be quite fiendish, yet once solved can be appreciated for their elegant simplicity. Learning to think in all directions at once was key to mastering the Swapper.

The story, too, echoes the theme of simplicity and complexity masking each other. On the face of it, the plot is quite straightforward, but it conjures up unnerving questions of identity and what it means to be alive; to be sentient. Coupled with the numerous computer logs positioned throughout the game, you get a real sense of what kind of world the Swapper takes place in. And a sense of how it could well be our own.

What would you do to survive?

reviewText:
The puzzles in this game were just right. I had to shake my head and give up on a few, but when I came back to them later I was always able to figure them out. In other words, they're really satisfying.

Likewise, the setting, atmosphere and story all align perfectly with the exploration the game calls for.

Finally, after finishing the game and contemplating the story for a while, I noticed that I had failed to get any of the games 10 achievements. Apparently these are comprised of secret rooms that I had no idea existed. I'm looking forward to playing through again in search of them.

reviewText:
This is one of the better puzzle games I've played. It offers a simple and straight-forward concept and utilises it to its full potential - create clones of yourself that copy your every move in order to solve puzzles. The puzzles vary between each other, and some introduce new things into the mix. For example not being able to create any clones within blue light, or not being able to swap between the clones within red light. In late stages the game also offers gimmicks with artificial gravity too, which adds a layer of complexity to the puzzles.

Most of the game has you solve puzzles in order to collect orbs, and a certain number of these is required to get past checkpoints to another area. I really liked this semi-open feel of exploration that the game offered, and for most of it you didn't even have to solve every single puzzle in order to make progress. You could afford to skip some. However, the very last console checkpoint requires that you solve every single puzzle that's left. Most of the puzzles were really intuitive and felt rewarding when you solved them, but I wasn't a fan of a few near the end. Three of the puzzles took me so many attempts that I eventually had to consult a walkthrough. I think that it would've been better if the final checkpoint didn't require every single puzzle to be solved.

Throughout exploring the ship and solving puzzles, there are many logs and interactable computer terminals that shed light on the creepy backstory behind this device that you're using to create clones. In general the story was in the background, but its concepts would leave you thinking of what's morally right, especially with the way it concluded with an interesting choice of two alternate endings.

All in all, I enjoyed the game and thought it was pulled off really well. Only the last few puzzles near the end frustrated me. Would certainly recommend it for all fans of puzzle games.

reviewText:
The Swapper is a great puzzle platforming game. The player is equipped with a device called the swapper, hence the game name. The device allows a person to create up to four clones at a time and can swap to control any of them. The puzzle revolves around these two core elements as you gain no additional abilities when the game progesses. However, new puzzle elements are added to keep you scratching heads. There is no narrator to tells you what the story is about. All that you have is gathered from space rocks and memory logs that tells you about the past. Throughout the game, it constantly portrays the questions about life and whether you are ready to sacrifice your humanity for survival. In the end, I  swapped myself with another person to survive.

The negative part about this game is the length which is considerably short, depending on how good you are with puzzle games. The hidden rooms which nets you steam achievement are literally impossible to find unless referring to a guide. It gives you no clue on how to get there. It just goes, hey I want a room in a dark spot above this wall. Other than that, The Swapper is an amazing experience.

9/10

reviewText:
The Swapper is phenomenal.

The gorgeous backgrounds and subdued music combine to create an immenly dense atmosphere - forlorn, derelict and sad one time, calm and almost soothing at others.
Gameplay consists mostly of puzzlesolving, and some very basic platforming. The puzzles range from easy enough to downright insidious, and solving the latter kind is immensly satisfying.
The Swapper's story is perplexing and will keep you wondering what's going on for quite a bit of the game - but in a good way, and whenever some of the pieces fell together and revealed parts of the bigger picture, it left me in awe.
First playthrough lasted 6 hours for me.

All in all, phantastic experience, would absolutely buy again.

reviewText:
First of all this is a story driven puzzle platformer.  It plays like Limbo, what that entails is the player character is floaty, the controls are rudimentary and the driving force is ingame/inengine cutscenes with a certain vagueness to them.  However it isn't linear like Limbo and has a Metroid Prime structure to it, with datalogs/internal monologues.  So that should give you an idea of how it will play and what you will experience.

With that said, the puzzles are simple at first, but get pretty devilish as the game progresses.  The music is fantastic.  The whole game feels like a visionary Sci-Fi classic, presenting you with the questions and some thoughts on them, but never supplying anything close to a concrete answer.  I don't know how to explain the graphics, but looks like a 3-D/claymation effect without really being either, in my opinion, which isn't a bad thing since I like the look.

I randomly started playing it one afternoon and could not stop.  The later puzzles might have been harder as a result of the extended session, but it was well worth it.  The Swapper was gripping from beginning to end.

reviewText:
An extremely good puzzle game with art that is mostly (possibly entirely?) made from real-life objects, giving it a very cool look. Even more impressive is the game's atmosphere, which is both solitary and very contemplative. Basically, this game made me want to go read some good sci-fi.

The puzzles are varied and most are challenging without being frustrating, and nothing requires split-second timing. My only complaint with The Swapper is that to complete it, you have to solve every single puzzle in the game. Until the end, the game's obstacles (unlocked using orbs you solve puzzles to collect) can be passed by solving most, but not all available puzzles. This lets you skip a handful that I found too difficult, even after trying over several days. The very end, however, requires you to go back and solve EVERYTHING. This was frustrating.

Also, if you're a lunatic for achievements, this game hides all its achievements and a fair amount of back story on ten hidden terminals. These aren't like Bioshock Inifinite audio-log hidden"
date: these basically require you to glitch through seemingly solid walls where there is no indication of a collectible. If it was just achievements hidden this way it would be stupid but easily ignored; the fact that there is additional story and flavor hidden so ridiculously deep is aggravating.\n\nMy quibbles with it are minor
recommended: though. The Swapper is a must for people who enjoy puzzle games and good atmosphere and mystery."

reviewText:
Ok the game is quite something for sure.

I'll briefly review the good(s) in game.

1. The gameplay is good.
2. The game mechanic is good.
3. The game mechanic is in relation with the plot.
4. This is not a puzzle-platformer. Just a puzzle. Which is good for most people who has little time in their hands, and just wants to burn a few away.
5. The puzzles are simple, yet complicated in a way in correlation with the game mechanic. It will make you think for a lengthy time. There were only 2 puzzles that I was stuck for a long time, but it may be so more or less to other people. These are not creativeness-dependent puzzles. These are puzzles which you need to be very observant to get through.
4. The music is soothing, wonderful, creepy, and scary all at the same time. It blends with the whole environment of the game.
5. The aesthetics and graphical fidelity are gorgeous. If I recall, they made most of everthing out of claymation or just clay.
6. The plot is unique as with most indies are. But this is rather a sad one.
10. You only have two(2) choices. Either you live your independence, or join in the great chain.

The story is rather obscure for most people who played the game. There are different explanations, but one thing is for sure.
You aren't controlling a person. You are controlling a clone.

If you finished the game, and want to know more about what the hell happened. Check out some interesting discussions at the game's forum.

I recommend this for people who likes puzzles. But not to people who are achluophobiac.

reviewText:
While deep philosphy in interactive entertainment is slowly becoming more commonplace, it's still an extremely rare occurance when majorly heady concepts  and themes are presented maturely, clearly, and accessible yet neither are hamfisted nor under-explored.  The Swapper immediately assumes you are an intelligent person and presents your mind a smorgasbord to feast upon.

At it's core The Swapper is a 2D puzzle platformer that uses a simple yet powerful gimmick to challenge the problem solving part of your brain.  You get a device called 'the swapper' and it allows you to create up to 4 clones of yourself which mimic each move you do.  You then can swap direct control between any which one in firing range and then chip away at some masterfully designed puzzles which remain challenging but never frustrating.

The narrative of the game is best left for discovery, but I will say it will please anyone with an affinity for sci-fi short stories.  The questions that askes you will have you long pondering its themes long after you take a break or finish the game.  And its themes are multifaceted and varied and I can easily see myself diving in for seconds and thirds.

Visually The Swapper is outstanding.  The vast majority of the visuals were crafted from clay and household items and work to give it a real organic feel.  Paired with a ambient sountrack that floats between giving sensations of isolation to painting portraits of beauty, they work in tandem to create an atmosphere that completely captivates you in the game world.

If you happen to be one of those psudo-intellectuals such as myself and enjoy chewing deep and philosphical questions and happen to love games as well, The Swapper is an experience well worth your time and money.  I can't speak highly enough of it.

reviewText: The Swapper is a science fiction platformer puzzle game that successfully balances difficulty with enjoyment. You, playing as the unknown, silent protagonist, explore a space station while using a gun" infused with technology capable of materializing clones on the spot and transferring your consciousness into said clones' bodies at will. Think of digistructing from Borderlands plus mind-control; that about sums up the mechanics. There are no enemies to encounter and the game allows plenty of time to think through the puzzles
date: which really do ramp up in difficulty as more variables are added and the game progresses. I'll admit I looked up directions on how to solve a puzzle or two in the beginning of the game when I was familiarizing myself with the mechanics
recommended: but I was ashamed of myself and grinded through the rest on my own
hoursPlayed: racking my brain to divine the correct solution... but when I finally DID solve a tricky puzzle? HUZZAH! Self-worth! Fist-in-the-air "YEAH! FINALLY!" celebrations! After feeling so brainless and idiotic struggling with a puzzle
voteText: completing it was extremely rewarding.\n\nThe plot is intriguing and
helpfulPercent: without spoiling anything
votesHelpful: makes the player ask thoughtful existential and philosophical questions about oneself
commentsCount: and what it is to "be." Throughout the game you sacrifice innumerable clones; a soaring mountain of these conjured meat sacks were killed during the time I had my finger on the trigger of the Swapper. They mostly died by smashing into the ground from extreme heights... hopefully the fall killed them instantly and painlessly. After all
column16: I was responsible for their deaths; they died during my attempt to escape the space station. I killed these poor souls. Hundreds of them. At least! But are they souls? Are they of worth? Are they YOU? Was it murder or... suicide? Or neither? Both? Am I still me if I'm living in a new body every few seconds? If the body didn't resemble mine
column17: would I still be me? Can being transfer between mediums? Does a soul exist independently from the body? Does consciousness transcend the material? These questions are particularly salient during the final scene
column18: which forces the player to make a gritty and difficult choice. This is real science fiction and demonstrates that video games can unquestionably qualify as art.\n\nI thought this would be a good game with which to use my gamepad
column19: but boy
column20: was I wrong. I do NOT recommend using a gamepad for The Swapper. Maybe it's just a personal lack of dexterity when using a gamepad (compared to a mouse and keyboard)
column21: but using the D-Pad and thumb sticks just didn't give me the precision and speed necessary to complete even the moderately difficult puzzles. The game took me about five hours to complete
column22: and that included finding all of the terminals and messages. I did NOT find the hidden rooms related to the achievements
column23: nor did I even attempt to do so. Even without them
column24: I was extremely satisfied with the length of the game and the story presented. The Swapper was a joy to play and left me very satisfied... yet unsettled. I'm still not sure about the choice I made at the end of the game... and I fear I might never be. Was it the right decision? Was there ANY right decision? Maybe you're just damned if you do and damned if you don't. Life is precious
