reviewText:
An indie title that is, shockingly, good. I'm not being facetious, I do believe that the majority of indie titles coast by easily on gimmicks such as 8-bit graphics or meme spouting that earn them undeserved praise among the gaming public. Some indie titles try way too hard to come off as intellectually stimulating and are heralded by people who are accustomed to triple A titles that stopped trying long ago. Being accustomed to ♥♥♥♥, they uphold anything that is remotely different as a godsend without looking at it individually and critically, falling prey to the hype and hysteria that comes with a community desperate to stick it to big name publishers by praising tiny developers without criticizing as readily due to a crowd that is too easily swayed by chiptune soundtracks or 8-bit graphics and faux-intellectualism.

Some of that is present here, sadly. The plot starts off by throwing you into the thick of things, giving you logs to read without any context or attempt to ease you more readily into the game's story. Soon enough (it's a short game, afterall) you're reading logs dealing with esoteric matters of what conciousness is and the difference between the mind, identity, and the physical. Admittedly, it compliments the games mechanic of swapping bodies and interweaves it in a commendable manner. But the way the developers go about informing you on these plot points is lacking. There's something to be said of storylines that don't go on long expositionary strings of dialogue and opt for weaving the plotline into the game through files, flashbacks, and other subtle forms. But it's a delicate art: you have to make sure the gamer isn't inundated with incomprehensible information from the outset, and have to slowly peal away the layers of the plot in a way that is simplistic and understandable. This game has sadly failed to master the art it so desperately wishes to practice. It wants to create a sense of loneliness through its absence of cut-scenes, yet opts to include a few mid-way through the narrative; it wishes to have you slowly figure out just what is occuring but instead leaves confusion.

By the end of the title, you have a solid enough grasp on the story to find the ending worthwhile. But that won't stop me from chastising the sloppy narrative at the outset. But the failures in story-telling are due to the successes in atmosphere. The developers wanted as much silence, loneliness, and eeriness as possible. While it succeeds in creating an ecosystem of melancholy and, strangely, sorrow, the trade-off was an explicit and concrete narrative. It's impossible to dictate the peculiarities of the overworld if you wish for everything to be as quiet and non-obtrusive as possible.

Ultimately, the narrative is really my only criticism. So far I've only complimented the developers success in their atmospheric goals. But let me add another one to the pile: the games mechanics. Ultimately, that's all we're here for, right? And the developer delivers. Gameplay revolves around a device that allows you to place clones of yourself throughout the world, empeded only by distance and light sources that dictate the terms of your abilities. Is the light source blue? You may only swap with existing clones. Red? The converse is our new reality: clone placement is acceptable but swapping isn't. Such a simple mechanic, but the developer has crafted a variety of puzzles that build on it and keep it fresh. It almost reminds me of Portal, really. One mechanic that is built upon and used in a variety of ways.

As a whole, the title is worthwhile and one of the few indie titles that legitimately deserves the praise it gets. But please, don't pester me about it's 'moving' plotline. While it definitely has points of interest, the manner in which it delivers them detracts from their otherwise perfect and original premises. It's a shame. But that fault aside, the game is an enjoyable puzzle game that stretches out a simple mechanic to its limits and has a style and atmosphere of its own to set it apart from other games. Being unique is quite possibly the one thing games strive for and what matters most, and this title presents a style that is worth noting. Titles like this are short enough that it's difficult not recommending them.

Wu-Tang motherfu*ker.

reviewText: A brilliant little thing. Simple mechanics that lend themselves to organic exploration, I found myself moving around obstacles because I figured out how I could do it with the tools available rather than because the game gave me a forty-minute tutorial and a dozen pop-up hints. The puzzle difficulty escalates nicely, the graphics are distinctive and the atmosphere is excellent. If you enjoy gameplay-based storytelling and want to play a horror game without combat, this is an excellent pick.

reviewText: Not since Portal 2 have I so enjoyed a really unique puzzle game. The Swapper has a beautiful soundtrack to play to and wonderful visuals of expansive space backdrops. The concept is fairly simple and but super enjoyable to play. It took me 6 hours to play it in its entirety, and I wish it was a little longer. A few puzzles had me stumped for while, one taking me as long as 30 minutes to solve. All around, this game was well worth the price paid. I hope there's a sequel or perhaps a prequel in development, as I would definitely love to play this style of gameplay again.

reviewText:
While deep philosphy in interactive entertainment is slowly becoming more commonplace, it's still an extremely rare occurance when majorly heady concepts  and themes are presented maturely, clearly, and accessible yet neither are hamfisted nor under-explored.  The Swapper immediately assumes you are an intelligent person and presents your mind a smorgasbord to feast upon.

At it's core The Swapper is a 2D puzzle platformer that uses a simple yet powerful gimmick to challenge the problem solving part of your brain.  You get a device called 'the swapper' and it allows you to create up to 4 clones of yourself which mimic each move you do.  You then can swap direct control between any which one in firing range and then chip away at some masterfully designed puzzles which remain challenging but never frustrating.

The narrative of the game is best left for discovery, but I will say it will please anyone with an affinity for sci-fi short stories.  The questions that askes you will have you long pondering its themes long after you take a break or finish the game.  And its themes are multifaceted and varied and I can easily see myself diving in for seconds and thirds.

Visually The Swapper is outstanding.  The vast majority of the visuals were crafted from clay and household items and work to give it a real organic feel.  Paired with a ambient sountrack that floats between giving sensations of isolation to painting portraits of beauty, they work in tandem to create an atmosphere that completely captivates you in the game world.

If you happen to be one of those psudo-intellectuals such as myself and enjoy chewing deep and philosphical questions and happen to love games as well, The Swapper is an experience well worth your time and money.  I can't speak highly enough of it.

reviewText:
+Fantastic sound design.
+Wonderfully stylized presentation.
+Polished graphics.
+Iterative innovation on proven game-play concepts.
+Mind-bending puzzles.

-Too short.
-Story misses a few minor beats.

The Swapper has quickly become a favored indie title of mine, surpassing top-notch titles like Fez and Braid. I am subjectively biased by the more serious tone and sci-fi setting though. The story is light, but engaging. The derelict space-station setting provides a miraculously haunting atmosphere. Characters are voiced adequately, though the performances border on becoming too withdrawn (which is part of the story/setting, but felt extreme at times). Very short, though still quite fulfilling. If most plot driven titles are novels, then The Swapper is ultimately a great poem; metered, personal, and interpretive. A beautifully sad journey and a striking metaphor for real human struggles with individuality.

Comparable games: Braid, Super Metroid, Portal

reviewText:
First of all this is a story driven puzzle platformer.  It plays like Limbo, what that entails is the player character is floaty, the controls are rudimentary and the driving force is ingame/inengine cutscenes with a certain vagueness to them.  However it isn't linear like Limbo and has a Metroid Prime structure to it, with datalogs/internal monologues.  So that should give you an idea of how it will play and what you will experience.

With that said, the puzzles are simple at first, but get pretty devilish as the game progresses.  The music is fantastic.  The whole game feels like a visionary Sci-Fi classic, presenting you with the questions and some thoughts on them, but never supplying anything close to a concrete answer.  I don't know how to explain the graphics, but looks like a 3-D/claymation effect without really being either, in my opinion, which isn't a bad thing since I like the look.

I randomly started playing it one afternoon and could not stop.  The later puzzles might have been harder as a result of the extended session, but it was well worth it.  The Swapper was gripping from beginning to end.

reviewText:
Had a blast with this one.

The story was enough to keep me intrigued without beating me over the head with cutscenes, and the central game mechanic itself ties in to the thought-provoking premise.

The puzzles were my favorite kind: the kind that make you feel brilliant when you figure them out but don't frustrate you endlessly beforehand. The various puzzle mechanics (including the the Swapper itself) are paced out very well.

My only complaint is that I would have loved to have more, and that's a good complaint to have. It means you just played a great game.

reviewText: It's an awesome platformer with a truly immersive eerie atmosphere created especially thanks to the unique visuals (claymation-based with well-thought lightings) and the uncanny soundtrack. There are no monsters to fight, just puzzles to solve in order to collect some orbs and progress to other areas, but the puzzles can get quite challenging, to say the least. The story is also captivating, though based on some rather intricate sci-fi concepts.\n\nOne of the few games that wants to make you feel lonely and lost, and manages to perfectly do so. I loved it in every aspect and I highly recommend it.

reviewText: Puzzle-based games rarely offer the depth and atmosphere The Swapper provides. The game takes place in a beautifully realized science fiction setting; as you traverse an enormous yet desolate research station orbiting an alien world, you begin to piece together an understanding of the events which led it to such a state. However, with each bit of information about the past that you uncover, new questions about the present begin to appear.\n\nOverall, The Swapper is a game that accomplishes a lot without overstaying its welcome. It's short enough (roughly 3 - 6 hours) that despite puzzle mechanics that are fairly limited in scope, it rarely feels repetitive, and it leaves you satisfied but wanting more. I'd highly recommend this game.

reviewText: From the first time I played this game, it was cemented in my mind as one of the absolute best Indie games of 2013. Posing questions about the nature of the individual identity, this game is one that will keep you questioning the ethics of the use of the swapper device - a device that can move your soul between clones. An absolutely superb game, it has it puzzles that will truly challenge you though I never found myself frustrated by it as each room presented a fresh challenge and the cryptic storyline truly kept me thoroughly engaged. This is a game I will definitely play multiple times. I highly recommend this game and it is an experience that will definitely stick in my mind for a very long time.

reviewText:
An indie title that is, shockingly, good. I'm not being facetious, I do believe that the majority of indie titles coast by easily on gimmicks such as 8-bit graphics or meme spouting that earn them undeserved praise among the gaming public. Some indie titles try way too hard to come off as intellectually stimulating and are heralded by people who are accustomed to triple A titles that stopped trying long ago. Being accustomed to ♥♥♥♥, they uphold anything that is remotely different as a godsend without looking at it individually and critically, falling prey to the hype and hysteria that comes with a community desperate to stick it to big name publishers by praising tiny developers without criticizing as readily due to a crowd that is too easily swayed by chiptune soundtracks or 8-bit graphics and faux-intellectualism.

Some of that is present here, sadly. The plot starts off by throwing you into the thick of things, giving you logs to read without any context or attempt to ease you more readily into the game's story. Soon enough (it's a short game, afterall) you're reading logs dealing with esoteric matters of what conciousness is and the difference between the mind, identity, and the physical. Admittedly, it compliments the games mechanic of swapping bodies and interweaves it in a commendable manner. But the way the developers go about informing you on these plot points is lacking. There's something to be said of storylines that don't go on long expositionary strings of dialogue and opt for weaving the plotline into the game through files, flashbacks, and other subtle forms. But it's a delicate art: you have to make sure the gamer isn't inundated with incomprehensible information from the outset, and have to slowly peal away the layers of the plot in a way that is simplistic and understandable. This game has sadly failed to master the art it so desperately wishes to practice. It wants to create a sense of loneliness through its absence of cut-scenes, yet opts to include a few mid-way through the narrative; it wishes to have you slowly figure out just what is occuring but instead leaves confusion.

By the end of the title, you have a solid enough grasp on the story to find the ending worthwhile. But that won't stop me from chastising the sloppy narrative at the outset. But the failures in story-telling are due to the successes in atmosphere. The developers wanted as much silence, loneliness, and eeriness as possible. While it succeeds in creating an ecosystem of melancholy and, strangely, sorrow, the trade-off was an explicit and concrete narrative. It's impossible to dictate the peculiarities of the overworld if you wish for everything to be as quiet and non-obtrusive as possible.

Ultimately, the narrative is really my only criticism. So far I've only complimented the developers success in their atmospheric goals. But let me add another one to the pile: the games mechanics. Ultimately, that's all we're here for, right? And the developer delivers. Gameplay revolves around a device that allows you to place clones of yourself throughout the world, empeded only by distance and light sources that dictate the terms of your abilities. Is the light source blue? You may only swap with existing clones. Red? The converse is our new reality: clone placement is acceptable but swapping isn't. Such a simple mechanic, but the developer has crafted a variety of puzzles that build on it and keep it fresh. It almost reminds me of Portal, really. One mechanic that is built upon and used in a variety of ways.

As a whole, the title is worthwhile and one of the few indie titles that legitimately deserves the praise it gets. But please, don't pester me about it's 'moving' plotline. While it definitely has points of interest, the manner in which it delivers them detracts from their otherwise perfect and original premises. It's a shame. But that fault aside, the game is an enjoyable puzzle game that stretches out a simple mechanic to its limits and has a style and atmosphere of its own to set it apart from other games. Being unique is quite possibly the one thing games strive for and what matters most, and this title presents a style that is worth noting. Titles like this are short enough that it's difficult not recommending them.

Wu-Tang motherfu*ker.

reviewText:
Very good puzzle game with quite innovative mechanics and gameplay. The difficulty is mediocre to hard and often uses really simple solutions that just didn't come to you that easily. What surprised me though was the really interesting and crazy story together with the abstract but convincing atmosphere and the presentation of it. It is even insane when you think that the developers were able to create a story out of such totally absurd mechanics and still make it entertaining and full of secrets.
It is for sure a puzzle game at first, but it also creates something unique on the meta-level which I could bet should surprise others just like me. The soundtrack and sound-effects are also really great and soothing and fit perfectly into the environment

Only thing I don't like is the way the achievements and the secrets are hidden, here the game lacks the innovation it shows everywhere else.

reviewText: Similar in style to Limbo, in that the subject matter is relatively bleak and it is 2D (i.e. 'flat') puzzler/platformer. The differences lie within the gameplay - The Swapper is more focused on puzzles with little to no consequences for dying, while Limbo is more focused on the platforming with death being frustrating aspect. A couple of the puzzles stumped me for a few minutes, but solving them was very rewarding (not sure I 'completed' some of the puzzles per intended fashion, but they were solved nonetheless). I would recommend this game to anyone - it's a short game, but it's also well worth the price.

reviewText:
The “artistic” puzzle/exploration game with strong philosophical undertones seems trendy of late. Especially with all these indie developers vying to be the one to finally get games recognized as “art”. But as Facepalm Games seems to understand, art isn’t about the destination. It’s about what brought you there.

The Swapper does not lack for artistic content. All of the visuals are made from clay models and other real-world materials, given a fancy shader to make your unnamed spaceman’s flashlight bounce off their surfaces realistically. It’s beautiful in its simplicity and effectiveness, invoking a mood very reminiscent of the cult-classic 1972 sci-fi movie Silent Running.

The Mr. Spaceman you play, comes across a strange device that lets you create clones and swap between them. All the clones mimic your movements exactly. The first time you get so caught up in solving a puzzle that you forget which one was “you” (which you then accidentally kill), is a very memorable moment. If a clone dies, it’s no big deal. You just make another. But there’s only one of you. Right?

The puzzles get tricky, but frustration is offset due to the open-world nature of the space station. While you are gated somewhat, multiple puzzles are available to you at any time. Exploration leads to discovery, and clues about the strange sentient rocks everywhere in the station.

reviewText: Ever since Jon Blow's Braid, indie platformers have flooded the digital market. It seems that every month we get a new game that either attempts to emulate Braid's successes or fail at developing it's own identity. The Swapper is the kind of evolution of this genre that should have happened after Braid.\n\nTasked with exploring a very eerie space station, your character stumbles upon a device that allows him to create a small number of clones of himself. Along with cloning, you can swap" between the clones with a press of a button. Once you obtain both features of your swapper gun
date: you are left to explore and solve puzzles to continue your journey.\n\nThe set up may be simple as hell
recommended: but the puzzles are very creative. Everything from lateral thinking to reaction based puzzles and even some that limit your clones from the standard 4. While this may have gotten boring if dragged on for more than a few hours
hoursPlayed: developer Facepalm Games knew to take their idea

pros: visuals & atmosphere, zero gravity sections, interesting & challenging puzzles with the swap mechanic, teleports readily available to traverse the expansive ship, eerie story & ending

The Swapper has my highest recommendation, a must play for puzzle game fans.

reviewText:
The Swapper is a sci-fi'ish sidescrolling puzzle platformer set on a space station far away from any civilization or help and utilizes a fairly unique puzzle mechanic where you use your Swapping device to create clones of yourself which will act and move the same way you do and will help you solve the numerous puzzles in the game to collect Orbs with which you can unlock further areas of the space station.

Without spoiling too much, the story isn't anything groundbreaking or innovative, but it's told in a fairly interesting manner and keeps you going. With the overall theme of the game, it actually proves to be quite deep if you pay attention and take the time to think about it for a bit.

As mentioned before, the main puzzle mechanic of the game is to create clones of yourself which move simultaneously with you and which you have to place in the right spots to trigger switches and so on. Additionally, you can freely switch between all created clones and take control of them so they become the 'main character', which is especially useful with puzzles where you tend to die.

Dying is actually a large part of the puzzle experience as you will have to first figure out how the puzzle is supposed to work before you actually solve it and that will definitely produce some, uh, collateral damage. Luckily enough, only your main character can actually die, which will cause you to respawn in the room you're currently in.

To add a bit of challenge to it, there are red, blue and purple lights placed in the enviroments, which will prevent you from either creating clones or swapping between them - or both. Around halfway through the game, another puzzle mechanic is introduced where you have glowing platforms on the ground and/or ceiling, that will alter gravity and basically flip you upside-down (similar to VVVVVV), which adds another tad of challenge to the puzzles.

Personally, and despite the above mentioned challenge mechanics, I found the puzzles to be fairly simple and relatively easy for the most part. There definitely were some tough nuts among them, but unfortunately those were the exception to the rule.

Visually, the game looks fairly cool and gets even cooler once you realize that all of what you see there 'is constructed using clay models and other everyday materials'. The lighting, depth of field and bloom also add a lot to the atmosphere of the enviroments, though I would've wished for a slightly brighter level design as some areas are literally pitch black.

With around 5 hours of playtime, The Swapper isn't overly long but feels just about right for the game. Unfortunately, it doesn't really offer any replay value unless you want to replay it for the sake of paying more attention to the story and dialogues.

As a PSA: If you plan to get the achievements in the game (which require you to find 10 hidden consoles), make sure to do it before you activate the final 124-Orb terminal, as this is a point of no return and you will have to replay the whole game again in case you missed any of the achievements.

All in all, The Swapper is a really impressive debut game of Finnish developer Facepalm Games and I'm definitely looking forward to see more quality games like this from them.

reviewText:
Ok the game is quite something for sure.

I'll briefly review the good(s) in game.

1. The gameplay is good.
2. The game mechanic is good.
3. The game mechanic is in relation with the plot.
4. This is not a puzzle-platformer. Just a puzzle. Which is good for most people who has little time in their hands, and just wants to burn a few away.
5. The puzzles are simple, yet complicated in a way in correlation with the game mechanic. It will make you think for a lengthy time. There were only 2 puzzles that I was stuck for a long time, but it may be so more or less to other people. These are not creativeness-dependent puzzles. These are puzzles which you need to be very observant to get through.
4. The music is soothing, wonderful, creepy, and scary all at the same time. It blends with the whole environment of the game.
5. The aesthetics and graphical fidelity are gorgeous. If I recall, they made most of everthing out of claymation or just clay.
6. The plot is unique as with most indies are. But this is rather a sad one.
10. You only have two(2) choices. Either you live your independence, or join in the great chain.

The story is rather obscure for most people who played the game. There are different explanations, but one thing is for sure.
You aren't controlling a person. You are controlling a clone.

If you finished the game, and want to know more about what the hell happened. Check out some interesting discussions at the game's forum.

I recommend this for people who likes puzzles. But not to people who are achluophobiac.

reviewText: This is one of the few greatest puzzle/plat forming games out there. There is much emphasis on plat forming but there is still enough in there to be called a plat former. The puzzle sections in this game are great. I would say the puzzles are not too hard and not too easy either. I would like to say that the puzzle is as good as the puzzles in portal. The idea of this game is to be able to create clones of yourself and place them in areas and switch minds with them to collect orbs. There are switches you need to hit; red light that prevents you from switching minds to a clone; blue light that prevents you to make clones; purple light which has the effect of both red and blue lights.\nThe bmg (Background Music) of this game is also great but i would imagine this is arguable with a lot of people so I may be in the minority on this one. The background graphics in this game look great with enough detail to things around you which will amaze you. Though i do not really like the player/human models in this game that much nor do i really like the animation of the characters but it didn't really get in the way with the gameplay. The controls are pretty decent but with a slight clunky" feel to it which doesn't really matter too much in most puzzle games but in some section which involves a little bit of plat forming elements can cause irritation.\nThe storyline gets in the way with the game. It not much of a story and I didn't even bother reading half of the note left around in the ship. Then again

the only puzzle game that has a good storyline to it is portal so i guess having a good storyline in a puzzle game in really needed.

The only issue I had with the game is that, while the game has two possible endings, you can't go back after you've seen one of them and re-do the last part of the game in order to watch the other one - you have to go through the entire game again. And after you've solved the puzzles once, there's little reason to revisit the game.

Aside from that, it's an awesome game.

reviewText:
A very fun and beautiful puzzle platformer which took me around 3 hours to complete; however, time may vary with luck and skill. The puzzles start off simple, but get very challenging and rewarding to complete towards the end of the game.

You have the ability to create clones of yourself, all of which are controlled simultaneously, to complete the puzzles. Elements are added to the puzzles as you progress: coloured lights which prevent the creation and/or possession of clones; standard pressure pads; reverse gravity pads.

The only minor issues with the game were the annoying zero-gravity sections and the un-skippable cut scenes (a long one I had to repeat because I crushed myself with an elevator).

It's an amazing game which isn't really that popular (at least I think anyway).

reviewText:
A gloomy puzzle platformer with esoteric and philosophical references and great visuals and mechanics, The Swapper is everything Braid should've been, and more.

HighlightsOne major benefit of The Swapper is in the lack of repetition. The puzzle mechanics are the same throughout the entire game but not once does it feel repetitive or samey. Variety keeps the landscape moving.

* Very challenging puzzles that force you to think to overcome
* Distinctive style that helps the game feel obscure and alien
* Subtle but powerful narrative

MistakesThis is such a well crafted game and the developers have clearly went for quality over quantity, opting to make sure everything is done right. There really are no glaring issues with The Swapper

* Maybe a little too hard towards the end for people looking for a more casual exploration
* Arguably too short, more content might've lifted the title a little higher

RecommendationsThe Swapper is priced at £11.99/13.99€/$14.99 which is fairy priced on the spectrum of games of this type, but some might consider it a little high when looking at its 5 hour playtime. Fortunately it regularly goes on sale for -50% or less.

It's also available on GOG where it's a little cheaper, and includes some wallpapers to boot.

* There are a number of hidden messages, achievements and rooms throughout The Swapper. You can view them here if you don't mind the spoilers

reviewText: Absolutely amazing game. Great and challenging puzzles, the learning curve is perfect, not easy by any means, but not hard enough to legitimately frustrate you. Atmosphere was great, very creepy and Super Metroid-esque. My only two complaints are both subjective and personal. I find the soundtrack a little bit lacking, and found myself playing my own music in the background because the nearly silent soundtrack put me on the brink of insanity(not literally). I don't know, maybe that is the point, having a spacey barely-there soundtrack just to give you the creeps. Again my own opinion. The other complaint is the story, maybe I'm just stupid and I completely missed the plot, or the story is just so spread and vague that no one knew what was happening. I think they tried to do something similar to Bioshock where survivors leave notes or recordings of their experiences etc. and you the player pick them up and infer what is going on. Although these memory stations are plenty, they are too vague to be of much value. Maybe it's like Inception, you kind of have to watch it like 5 times to get what exactly is going on.

reviewText:
TL;DRThe Swapper is a stunning game with its atmosphere, soundtrack, narrative, and graphics commending each other extremely well.

ReviewThe Swapper has a a rather dark narrative, with the plot  developing through moments of curiosity, to realization, and to sufferance. (Spoiler, hover over black area to reveal text)
This game truly portrays the story in entirely pertinent fashion.
Its somber, progressively haunting atmosphere is incredibly satisfying to play through.
For a 2D Puzzle Platformer, the graphics/art style suits it so well.
An occasional parallax effect on the background is not overdone at all and is extremely fit for the scene when used.
The long and drawn out shadows combined with the aforementioned atmosphere compliment each other extremely well.
The bloom effects can become a bit much, but I personally loved them.
They gave a feeling quite reminiscent of a dusty, abandoned area which is the main setting for most of the game despite some well lit areas. (Spoiler, hover over black area to reveal text)
All of these combined with the soundtrack in The Swapper bring out a rather solemn sentiment throughout the game.
This last feature was the one that really, really sucked me into this game. Kind of like reading a really sad part in a book. You want to keep on reading but as you read, you just start to get the feels.


Overall, I give this game a solid 9.5/10

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine
The Swapper is a sci-fi platformer game developed by Facepalm Studios and follows a spaceman trapped on a spaceship. You recieve a device known as a Swapper which basically clones you to up to four different clones. Over the course of the game you have to collect orbs by solving not difficult, not easy, but challenging puzzle games to collect these orbs and completing certain objectives

Overall the game is amazing, the backgrounds and the characters are all made in clay and uses the stopmotion technique for movements and such. This amazed me to bits, and the environments and atmoshpere blend in well with the sound effects and visual effects of the game

The music fits well in this game too, The Swapper's minimalistic music made me feel like I'm alone on this spaceship and the atmosphere alone made me scared and on my toes to think that there are any enemies about, which thankfully there isn't. The very little voice acting there is is also played very well

The puzzles as mentioned before are not difficult, not easy but challenging. Some of the puzzles require you to find a solution, especially the ending puzzles. All puzzles need to be completed to encounter the ending and all 124 orbs need to be collected. It may look a lot, but there are only 42 puzzles in the whole game

The length of the game really made me upset, I completed the game in under 4 hours, which is so short for such an visually beautiful game, but with the challenging puzzles, I am glad to say that I finished the game in that length of time

The only complaint I have is the Swapper device itself, for you to create a clone you have to press the RMB, sounds simple enough and it is, and the LMB is used to teleport to that clone you created. The complaint I have is that sometimes I press the LMB and nothing happens, and if there is a bit where I am falling and need to get on a ledge and I create a clone and press the LMB and nothing happens, I die and have to do it again! Thankfully, the game has an extremely fair checkpoint system so it's not a big of an issue

The Swapper is a visually striking and atmospheric game. It pulled me in into its 4 to 5 hours playtime and has an amazing story which kind of reminded me of Frictional Games' SOMA and the ending made me question myself if I made the right decision or not

The Swapper I would highly recommend to anyone but it's not for everyone, the challenging puzzles can put some players off, but with some googling and walkthroughs, you can get through the challenging puzzles. The Swapper is an amazing sci-fi platformer game that everyone should give a go. Whether they like an interesting story, love sci-fi as a genre or challenging puzzles

date: etc... So I have decided to make my own!)"

https://youtu.be/8h3F8oNE-tQ

Seemingly abandoned on a deserted station in deep space, your only goal is to find a way off.  Soon however upon acquiring a 'swapping' device you learn things are not quite what they seem.

At the core of this game is a puzzle platformer, use the swapper device to place clones around the environment to solve room after room collecting mcguffins to unlock the next area.

The found object visual style of tin can rocketships adds to the unease of the rest of the aesthetic of gloom and despair.

reviewText:
Wow.

I don't think I've ever played a game like The Swapper. As far as recent platformers go, Braid and The Swapper are best there are. Not just in terms of invigorating gameplay, but the writing and music, they're so strong. The atmospher in The Swapper was gorgeous, beautiful and breathtaking. The animation was simple, but it didn't need much to show off, it already had the intriguing intro to keep the player going. The puzzles are strange and sometimes complex.

In The Swapper, you play a stranded astronaut, or scavenger that lands onto an abandoned space ship, Theseus, or at least it appears abandoned. It is one of seven ships meant to gather resources for Earth, as Earth has exhausted all resources. You have to find a means to esacpe, by solving puzzles, collecting orbs, collecting data to find out what happened to the crew and why they were so keen into the telepathic rocks/Watchers. The story is mystifying and refreshing for its ambiguity and intelligence of space, time, the mind, and life. It's almost philosophical.

I can't say I've played a game where you can generate clones and swap bodies, while controlling them all at the same time to solve puzzles. I know other platformers use the clone ability for puzzles, i.e.; Braid with its time controlling, Mario for its bizarreness, and a few others. But The Swapper perfects it for forcing you to use your clones, not to your advantage, but to your necessity.

It's fascinating to know that The Swapper's art, sets, characters were all claymation. It give itself a distinct art style you wouldn't reguarly see in videogames, especially since most video game art is done digitally. So seeing the seemless claymation in a videogame just goes to show that claymation is not a dying art form. I would certainly like to see more indie video games take this approach, as it is unique and, when done well, looks outstanding.

I can't say enough about this game, it's simply outstanding.

10/10

reviewText:
The swapper is a decent puzzle platformer with decent ambience, fresh gameplay mechanics and in my view, some of the most beautiful backgrounds yet seen in a sidescroller.

My one major gripe with some of the game's design choices center around the developers decision to use really thin fonts in the logs that expand on the story. Probably won't be an issue for most users, but if you have problems reading in low light, you may need to occasionally head over to a wiki to read up the terminal logs.. otherwise you might end up missing a rather thought-provoking story. Still highly recommended however.

p.s: The achievements in this game be maybe impossible to find on your solo playthrough. Unless you are extremely lucky, you are going to need a guide. Go for it, as you can't revisit the unlocked stages to get them once the credits roll.

Good luck.

reviewText:
The Swapper is one of the best puzzle games I've played. The puzzles get challenging fast, but they're designed in a way that the solution always seems within reach. Sometimes it's more straightforward than you thought, but the more devious ones are more complicated than they first seem. Either way, sometimes I'd just enter a room, try to figure out the riddle, then quit out the game and take a break if I didn't find a solution. But I never had the temptation to check out a guide. I loved the design in the puzzles too much to succumb to that. It's also way too satisfying to figure it out on your own, even if some are complex.

Basic concept of The Swapper is that you can create up to 4 clones of yourself, which behave exactly like you do, and you can swap consciousness with them. The consequence is that the body you leave behind is just an empty vessel, which you can use as a tool, a means to an end.

The developers actually run with this concept and a big part of the (surprisingly great) story revolves around the clones and the concept of a soul and the complexity of mind and matter. The story resonates because you are constantly hands-on with the overarching theme of the game. If you have to do a cruel thing to one of your clones, it hits home. The memorable finale is a culmination of all the soul-searching (and swapping) you had to do to get there.

The Swapper could've just been a series of brilliant puzzles and I would've loved it already, but they fleshed it out and created an interesting universe around it. To top it all off, there are the numerous echoes of Metroid and Alien, giving you an eerie sense of isolation.

Rarely do you get such a flawless fusion of gameplay, concept and story. This game is a gem, that a lot of people seem to be sleeping on. You shouldn't. Play it, it's brilliant.

reviewText:
I started playing this one just before procuring a short-term office job - one which walks that thin tight-rope between being utterly mindless and requiring just that teeny weeny bit of mental concentration - and I'm afraid that this game has been a temporary casualty of said event.  In other words I've thrown in the towel for the time being, but most certainly NOT because this isn't a ♥♥♥♥ING EXCELLENT GAME.

See, I'm over 40 now, and despite having not consumed all THAT much alcohol for a human of my years, I still only have so many brain cells to go around...and a large number of them have recently been dedicated to the practices of getting up ridiculously early (like, before MIDDAY, for ♥♥♥♥'s sake), showering and dressing (in more complicated clothes than a pair of shorts and a t-shirt with holes in it), brushing my teeth and hair, spraying on some deodorant, then getting on a bus and doing a six hour shift - that's SIX MOTHER♥♥♥♥IN' HOURS, goddammit - in which I fiddle with reams of paperwork.  So when it comes time to drag my weary ♥♥♥♥ home and put on some well-earned games, I'm really not up to anything which requires as monumental a mental effort as this absolute little GEM of a puzzle-platformer.  This game is SMART, yo.  Almost too smart for me at the best of times, and frankly way over my head in its current state of cerebral short-circuit.

So yes, after getting, I dunno, maybe half-way or so through it, I've had to put this game aside for the time being...but believe me when I say I WILL be coming back to it.  Between the ingeniously imaginative clay-built visuals, the cleverly-implemented cloning device your character uses to multiply himself, and the completely logical yet sometimes mind-♥♥♥♥ingly hard puzzles themselves, this game has QUALITY written all over it.  Highly recommended to anyone with an IQ at least slightly above that of a well-bred chimp (which isn't me right at this moment in time, sad to say)...

Verdict: 9.5/10.

reviewText:
This reminds me of Portal 1, except it was entertaining.

The game uses a clone puzzle mechanic. Some puzzles are difficult, while others are 'oh, I just needed to do that?'. You need to think sometimes.

Art direction is unique and you've NEVER played a game that looks like it.

The real cream on this cake comes from the plot. It's got philosophy; plus, it doesn't cross the line and muddle it with junk science. Unlike the god awful movie Prometheus which was marred worse than a 6 year old to a rabid dog, the science is rarely talked about in The Swapper, and the ambiguous themes are made known.

There are two endings (maybe a third, I don't know; probably not) and I chose to retain my identity, even if it were for a minute longer. Yes, the story makes you think, too.

reviewText: The Swapper is a puzzle game whose central mechanic is the ability to create clones of yourself and then take control of them. These clones all move together, so positioning them can be tricky and its further complicated by coloured areas that prevent either the creation of a clone, or swapping to it. The goal is to collect enough orbs to pass checkpoints. Early in the game when stuck on a puzzle you can skip it and solve another, but by the end you have to solve everything. I was disappointed that there are no new abilities to add new mechanics later in the game. Length depends on how quickly you solve the puzzles, took me 6 hours but I used a guide because my last 3 puzzles had me totally stumped. The story is weak. You're dropped in with no explanation of who you are or what is happening and by the time it provided some answers, I'd lost interest. I don't mind a mystery, but you have to start me off with a reason to care. Overall I could only recommend this to hardcore puzzle fans.

reviewText: This is one of the best puzzle games I ever played in my entire life. The game immediately strikes the eye with a very atmospheric setting. The whole environment is beautifully crafted. To fully enjoy this, playing on a high resolution is recommended. The originality of this game is out of question. By creating clones of yourself, you have to try to get to things. The game slowly gets you going to get used to the cloning mechanics. The puzzles are challenging enough to give you a sweat, but never leave you frustrated. As the game goes on, the story unfolds with messages coming in different forms. The story evolves very well and wants you to solve the puzzles even more. The only downside I can think of is that the end comes to soon. If you like puzzle games, you won't be disappointed by this masterpiece.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The Swapper is a puzzle platformer set in deep space. The premise is simple: you can clone yourself up to four times and take control of one of these clones at the same time. This unique gimmick also grants a number of unique puzzles. And these puzzles are great. The game rarely tells you what to do, only explains some basics and the rest is up to you.

The puzzles themselves are highly enjoyable, challenging and really require you to think outside of the box. However, a few of these puzzles are so insanely difficult that even the most seasoned puzzlers have to kill the pride any puzzle game can offer, and look for help on the web. Other puzzles require such pinpoint precision that even that becomes frustrating.

Difficulty aside I have nothing to complain about. The graphics are gorgeous, supposedly entirely made from clay, but I would've believed it to be the U3 engine just as well. The setting is really dark, a bit creepy even and perfectly fits with the idea of a derelict space station. There's some replayability for finding hidden rooms and an alternate ending, but puzzlers lose their charm after the solution has been found.

One final applause for the story of the game, which is just as mindblowing as some of the later puzzles. Hollywood quality writing there, with plenty of room for your own interpretation. I should, however, tell you as little about it as possible.

Looking for a challenge? Looking for a great puzzler? Looking for an awesome, open-ended story? The Swapper won't disappoint you.


+ Unique mechanics and puzzles
+ Challenging!
+ Wonderful setting and fitting graphics
+ Mindblowing story

- Too challenging?


8.5/10

reviewText:
This game is hands down the most beautiful game I have ever played. The effort put into making everything in this game out of  clay and then putting the graphics into the game really paid off. The beautiful atmosphere coupled with the ambient noise establishes one of the most haunting environments in any video game. Also, the lack of NPCs in this game establishes the lonlieness and brings the gamer to question why they are here and what is going on here.

The simple mechanic that is 'The Swapper' is really well done throughout the entire game and the puzzles are very challenging. The puzzles are very creatively imagined and the beginning levels teach you a lot of what you are going to see in the future. The game very carefully introduces new themes and mechanics that keep building on top of one another.

If you don't have this game you are really missing out on a great experience.
10/10 would reccomend to anyone

reviewText:
The Swapper is a puzzle platformer set in deep space. The premise is simple: you can clone yourself up to four times and take control of one of these clones at the same time. This unique gimmick also grants a number of unique puzzles. And these puzzles are great. The game rarely tells you what to do, only explains some basics and the rest is up to you.

The puzzles themselves are highly enjoyable, challenging and really require you to think outside of the box. However, a few of these puzzles are so insanely difficult that even the most seasoned puzzlers have to kill the pride any puzzle game can offer, and look for help on the web. Other puzzles require such pinpoint precision that even that becomes frustrating.

Difficulty aside I have nothing to complain about. The graphics are gorgeous, supposedly entirely made from clay, but I would've believed it to be the U3 engine just as well. The setting is really dark, a bit creepy even and perfectly fits with the idea of a derelict space station. There's some replayability for finding hidden rooms and an alternate ending, but puzzlers lose their charm after the solution has been found.

One final applause for the story of the game, which is just as mindblowing as some of the later puzzles. Hollywood quality writing there, with plenty of room for your own interpretation. I should, however, tell you as little about it as possible.

Looking for a challenge? Looking for a great puzzler? Looking for an awesome, open-ended story? The Swapper won't disappoint you.


+ Unique mechanics and puzzles
+ Challenging!
+ Wonderful setting and fitting graphics
+ Mindblowing story

- Too challenging?


8.5/10

reviewText: A beautiful gem of a game. Much more philosophical than I thought and yet it was everything I hoped for when it comes to a puzzle/platformer game. It forced me to think really really hard to solve some of the puzzles out there. Starts simple enough and then the difficulty gradually ramps up and you have to really be creative and ingenious to figure out how to get some of these orbs.\n\nMy only knock against the game is the achievements. They're too devious. Hidden behind walls, with no clue where to go on, you literally have to either try cloning yourself on every wall you encounter or watch a video walkthrough to find them. Otherwise, odds are you'll just finish the game without seeing a single one of them.

reviewText:
I'll start by saying to pick this up on sale. There isn't a ton to it, but it took me about 7-8 hours to finish. If you have an easier time with the harder puzzles, you might go faster. Once I knew the solutions, I could run through it again in under an hour, so it's really a two play-through game. More on that later.

First, the game looks great. I grabbed it for the appearance and ambience and was not disappointed there. It is very creepy and pulls off its intended asthetic well. The lighting is done extremely well.

You start by landing on a mysterious planet after having been sent off a space station in a drop pod. Then you find a device that lets you clone yourself and move into the different clones. You use this to solve puzzles and a story is slowly put in front of you. Often the clones will die, and often you will have to kill them to solve the puzzle. I went from not liking this, to not caring when I found out it didn't matter, then finished wondering if it actually did matter, but not being sure.

As far as the story, it is told well. Most of the game, I thought it was a good story. There are some strange things going on, though the story might actually reveal a little too much that would have been better left mysterious. Eventually there will be a big reveal that is somewhat meaningful. Also, subtitles will matter, and I'd recommend having them off on your first play, then running through it again with them on.

There are two endings. One is supremely unsatisfying and even stupid, and the other is questionable, but at least interesting.  Unfortunately, it autosaves but does not allow multiple load points. And one of these saves is the credit sequence. In an unbelievably silly oversight, in order to see the second ending, you have to run through the entire game again. And you can't go back and watch one of the several dialogue sequences either.

Ultimately, I'm glad to have played the Swapper, but I'm also glad I didn't pay full price.

reviewText:
The first thing I want to make clear is that this is not a bad game. It's actually a very thought-provoking, puzzle-intense, short-but-sweet sci-fi adventure with elements reminescent of movies such as Moon, or Alien (sans the jump scares). It's well done for an indie title, and its high metascore is deserved. It's just... not my kind of title, and I don't want to recommend a game based on what it does well, but how -I- enjoyed it.

The core element of this game, its raison d'etre, is the ability to create clones of yourself and to swap into those clones to explore and advance, while attempting to escape an abandoned craft. There are a number of puzzles woven into the narrative that at times stunned me at their cleverness, and the story really makes you think about what constitutes 'you' rather than 'your mind'--but I won't get into spoilers.

Where the game falls short is just -how- frustrating some of these puzzles can be, and frankly, a number can be a bit tedious. Games like Quantum Conundrum can get away with this because of the humorous and light-hearted atmosphere to keep you entertained, but here, the story elements can sometimes feel a bit few and few between. That, and I kind of feel like the game is a little... pretentious? Like it's trying -too hard- to make you think, and it throws you into the story in media res and makes you put the pieces together, as though that makes it deeper than it naturally is.

Other than that, the game doesn't have much else that stands out to me. Visuals are decent, as is the voice acting, but there's scarcely a sound track, and the hidden secrets in this game are -insanely- hard to find without a guide. I found myself both bored and frustrated more than I did intrigued and delighted, and that's a kiss of death for me when it comes to puzzle platformers.

Maybe this is someone else's cup of tea, but it's just not mine.

reviewText:
In a word: An undercooked story.

The Swapper is an atmospheric puzzle game with a partial focus on philosophy. I stress the word partial because I went into it expecting more by way of philosophy of mind and was left disappointed by its unwillingness to follow through with a number of themes it establishes early on. While the game’s central mechanic - the use of a gun to create clones - concerns the idea that the soul can endure different bodies, and the story concerns a race of advanced aliens who've transcended their bodies, the game clearly favours testing players with puzzles over getting them to ruminate over the story. The puzzles themselves are decent, unlike the atmosphere, which is genuinely great, as are are the claymation animations, which provide some splendid death scenes. About a year ago the writer, Tom Jubert, went explained why he didn’t think the writing integrated with the gameplay perfectly and having now finished the game, I completely agree with him. There’s a decent puzzle game in there and it's enjoyable enough but I think it bites off more than it can chew.

Recommended for people who like to think their minds and bodies are separate but really just wanna solve puzzles.

Length: 4 hours; Difficulty: Medium/High; Spaceships: Check

reviewText:
A beautiful and philosophical game with a single mechanic involving cloning and swapping between these clones. many puzzle platformers with a single mechanic gets boring and repetetive very fast, but not this game. because it uses this single mechanic in different clever ways and varies things up in a great pace. it is similar to fez in that regard; a single mechanic and a vast world to explore that gives the player the freedom to think outside the box and utilize their power in various scenarios.
This game truly fits on the shelf among other indie heavy hitters such as limbo, braid or journey

on a side note: This game reminded me of the infinite ocean" a free flash game available on armor games. its story is very different from the swapper and it is not even the same game genre. it's a point and click. but if you liked the swapper i can strongly recommend the infinite ocean because they share the same mysterious and haunting alone-in-space atmosphere and deals with the same tropes and concepts. asking similar mind blowing philosophical questions that really makes you think."

reviewText:
Play this game.  The gameplay gimmick is legitimately clever, the atmosphere is powerful and consistent throughout, and in a few short hours the is some legitimate ethical heavy lifting going on.  This game lives and breathes the spirit of weighty, lived-in 70s era science fiction movies.

Some of the puzzles are less intuitive than others and your character is static in terms of abilities and powerups from beginning to end, but this is exactly the sort of philosophically engaged cooperative storytelling that games should be capable of and I guarantee that, minor though it may seem, the implications of the ending choice will stick with you after the credits roll, informed by everything you played through before.

If you appreciate your sci-fi atmospheric, cinematic, morally challenging, and more than a little clever, do yourself a favor and play The Swapper.

reviewText:
Definitely recommended.
The game is amazing, every bit of the levels and chambers is very well designed and lovely to look at. The use of clay for modelling gives the game an overall tactile and realistic feel, in a way that is different from graphics quality.

Gameplay is enjoyable and is not by any means frustrating. Controls are responsive and rebind-able. Hooray for rebind-able controls!

The game itself .. The story is very intriguing and will surely appeal if you like a good mystery. The concept of cloning is very interesting, and leaves me with a bit uncomfortable and asking many questions about human significance and morality.

Worth every penny.

reviewText:
This game is the definition of atmospheric. It looks great. It sounds great.

Story:
I have to say, I am impressed as to how they came across telling it.
In Swapper you explore the Station Theseus, in a Metroidvania style, solving the mystery as to what happened, and why it happened.
(If you don't know what a metroidvania is, just google it)
Beware, there are 2 endings to the game at the end. Make the right choice.

Gameplay:
The game itself is a collection game. Get # orbs to activate # things.
You solve these puzzles to get these orbs to advance the game and therefore the story.
I honestly don't care about this. I enjoyed the game mechanics as much as I enjoyed the story of it all.
The puzzles were great. They utilized the game mechanics perfectly.
In order of game mechanics appearing: cloning/swapping, buttons, lights that prevent you from cloning/andor/swapping, gravity changing.
Slowing down time is a vital mechanic that made this game so much fun as well.
Mid way through the ramped up the difficulty of the puzzles. I admit I had to use a few guides to figure them out.

Visuals/Sound:
This game looks so good. The claymation was fantastic, I didn't even know it was clay at first until I read it somewhere.
And the sounds were satisfying to hear. I sometimes ran forward/back just to hear the doors slide open/closed.

The achievements in this game are secret terminals that you have to search for.
Make sure you try to find them before you activate the 124 terminal though, that's the point of no return.

7/10 This game impressed me. The storys great. The puzzles are great. And it looks and sounds great.
Why are you still reading this? Buy this game already. It's also available for PlayStation now if you're into that.

reviewText:
An absolute fantastic puzzle\platformer with atmosphere, a great soundtrack, intuitive puzzles\level design; and with just enough of a story to keep you interested. The game shines from it's simplicity; but yet challenging enough that it's not a cakewalk.

I beat the game in ~7 hrs; and most of the puzzles took ~5-8 minutes average (longer for the last few that really make you think).

My only con is that there isn't more!

If you like simple puzzle games with atmosphere, then for the price (especially if on sale) you can't go wrong.

8\10

reviewText:
A one-of-a-kind puzzler that rivals the Portal franchise in its ability to hijack the mind of the player, train the brain and steal your day away.

Atmospheric, hypnotic and beautiful, The Swapper is a fascinating and addictive maze of challenges that immerses the player and demands both concentration and adoration.  Did someone say that dinner is ready?  Not unless it's a baked orb and there's a ride on a long distance teleporter involved!

Pick this masterpiece up today and get addicted to swapping your way off this planet!

reviewText:
The Swapper is a simple little puzzle/adventure game that ultimately fails to impress. While the cloning and swapping mechanic is neat and some of the later puzzles can be head-scratchers, the game lacks cohesion between its individual elements, leaving the experience somewhat hollow.

The game begins with you in control of a nameless astronaut after being ejected, for reasons unknown, from a space station orbiting an alien planet. As you emerge from your escape pod planetside, you begin your quest to discover exactly what is going on. It's not long before you find the titular Swapper device, which allows you to create clones of yourself (that respond to control inputs in time with you) and transfer your control perspective between them as long as you have a line of sight. After getting a handle on the mechanics, you quickly come back aboard the space station Theseus, only to find it virtually devoid of life. It's here that the game begins properly, and sticks itself in a very basic loop until the end. You traverse the ship, solve puzzles to find energy-orbs, then use the orbs to power devices that open new sections of the ship.

The problem with this is that while the game is supposedly about uncovering a mystery, there is no mystery whatsoever in its environment. Each orb is found within its own little isolated room with its own little puzzle. And since these rooms exist only to hold the puzzles, it makes the entire space station feel less like a place where people lived and worked and more like an excuse to give the player some downtime in between puzzles. After all, why would space explorers and researchers need a room with two man-sized switches on opposing sides of the same platform that control colored lights that limit the use of the Swapper? The rest of the Theseus is equally impractical in its design, requiring extensive use of the Swapper just to get around. Granted, it would've been pretty boring to not use the game's central gimmick during map traversal, but the whole thing still feels like shallow pretense.

A potential alternative to these issues could have been to have the space station be thoroughly destroyed, with the orbs placed evenly throught the station rather than in rooms dedicated to them. Crumbling walls, collapsed ceilings, generally broken machinery and other structures could have made the Swapper's unnatural traversal method fit more naturally in the setting. Alternatively, the developers could have done away with the station entirely, making the game nothing more than a series of puzzles chosen from a menu, perhaps with a basic level editor included so the community could create and share their own puzzles, maybe even compete for best times or fewest Swaps a la Portal. But perhaps that suggestion is out of line, as this game has a story that it wants to tell.

The plot is one aspect of this game that I have no major gripes against. The dialogue is natural, it raises some philosophical and ethical questions about the nature of consciousness, the mystery unravels at an appropriate pace, and its general tone and themes are accompanied well by the visuals and music. My only criticisms are that the cutscenes are unskippable (but thankfully on the short side) and that there are two endings decided by a final binary choice. Normally I wouldn't mind that sort of thing, but unless you do some clever save file manipulation, you'll have to replay the game a second time to see the other one. And since you've already solved all the puzzles and seen all the unskippable cutscenes, it's pretty boring the second time around. The only potential saving grace of a subsequent playthough is finding the hidden text logs to get the achievements, but the vast majority of them are so obtusely hidden, it's unlikely you'll find them without a guide (unless you're a fan of trying to create clones in areas that look like totally solid walls, anyway). And they don't even tell you anything about the story you didn't already know.

However, all of that said, this game can be reasonably enjoyable for exactly one playthrough. It's very pretty to look at, pleasurable to listen to, and it story and puzzles will definitely give you some things to ponder. If that sort of thing intrigues you, maybe grab it when it's on sale for about $5 or so. Just don't expect anything brilliant or amazing here.

reviewText:
This game is unique. But that's not necessarily a good thing. Its story, gameplay and visuals all bring some novelty to the table but that couldn't save it from getting boring after about an hour of playing.

The problem is that the puzzles never evolve past what you see from the start of the game. They are also unpleasantly inconsistent in difficulty.

There are some fascinating ideas presented in the universe this game places you in. But again, the narrative frequently lost me by being too mysterious and lacking in any characters worth caring about.

This review isn't a resounding No
date: don't play it!" Instead I'd just caution you to not get caught up in all the high soaring reviews this game has received unless you are the type of person that can't get enough of 2D platform puzzlers filled with mystery and ambience."

reviewText: It is a neat idea and was sort of fun until I got frustrated and couldn't figure out any more puzzles after about the 35th one, so I gave up. I would've kept trying but the game is just boring to the point of wanting to quit and uninstall it and forget it ever existed and play something else. The difficulty spike is also what killed this stone dead: puzzles 1-35 are mostly a breeze, then the difficulty spikes up very hard, very quickly. Never seen a game spike like this. They thought that this game was good enough to be in its world long enough to figure a puzzle out and it just isn't, but Portal 2 is. Some puzzles in Portal 2 you may be there a while but you won't mind being there. In this game I just couldn't wait to turn it off and play something else. It's not a bad game, it just wasn't enough fun to keep going. Where Portal 2 is hard but fun I found this hard and more frustrating than fun. It is still okay but I only recommend it on a big sale. Much better indie games are out there just keep looking because this one is easily passable with no loss.

reviewText:
A new and creative concept with nice music and good atmosphere. But that does not save the game from being incredibly frustrating and repetitive.

The puzzles are mainly made up of pressing buttons that switch red and blue lights off and on, and your having 4 clones that you have to use to solve them. They are made more frustrating by bad controls.

For example, if you tap the jump button your character barely lifts from the ground, in what seems like a unnecessary move in the game, I found no use for it anywhere. And if you hold in the jump button, the character performs what I would characterize as a normal jump. There are boxes which you have to jump over and drag/push, and too often you don't hold the button long enough, causing the character to instead tilt the box and make it roll away from you, instead of jumping over it. First time I've experienced this in a puzzle/platformer game and it's so bad it almost becomes a deal breaker in itself. Developers could learn a thing or two from Mark of the Ninja, or other platformers with tight controls.

At first the atmosphere was great and the music augmented that in a very nice way. Unfortunately, once you start rolling boxes around when you mean to jump over them, and you experience the flap" sound of your clones dying and dying and dying
date: after you try one puzzle after another
recommended: you quickly get bored to death. Puzzles are not necessarily hard
hoursPlayed: but with the way they are organized it takes time to move around the room and solve them
voteText: even if you know and see what the solution is. And you often have to switch to another clone mid-air. If you miss that switch by 1/10 of a second and die for the nth time

reviewText:
The gameplay: Kinda neat; also kinda scarce. A novel mechanic like the swapper is rare and fascinating, but I almost spent more time running through hallways of intermittent exposition than actually solving puzzles.

The visuals: Kinda neat; eventually pretty same-ey. Everything just looks like a chunky blue blur after a while.

The story: Super lame. So many ideas are hinted at but never addressed. It feels like the writer was afraid to answer any of his deep" questions for fear that someone playing the game might disagree with him. The game ends in a disappointing binary choice
date: having discarded or forgotten half a dozen promising possibilities.\n\nBuy if you like puzzles and are patient enough to wade through all the navel-gazing to get to them."

reviewText:
I've played this game twice. Rather an interesting concept in the game and the puzzles are enjoyably crafted, though a few require more twitch reflex skills than out of the box thinking and discovery. It has beautifully crafted atmosphere and unrelenting loneliness, and the section with radiation and zero-G are exceptionally fun.

But that's where the good ends. This game is burdened with two huge things. Non-Intergrated Puzzlers and a story that doesn't even begin to ask the question let alone even provide enough background to surmise your answers.

A bane of puzzlers, pretty much all the key puzzles are rooms, set aside from all the rest to perform route actions to acquire security keys. The rest of the rooms tend to have obvious, at best, to the solutions the problems with. Swap gravity with plates, use clones and swap to when falling. Getting to some of the secret rooms take some doing, but of course they also require you to know there are invisible openings in the walls or when the foreground covers the screen, you to guess that Oh hey
date: I should jump!" which you'll find more from cocking about than honest exploration. And this is ignoring

reviewText: The Swapper is a puzzle plattformer, but I wouldn't call this game a plattformer. You don't have to go through difficult jump passages and there aren't enemies or something similar in the game. You just walk from room to room to solve puzzles with your clones to unlock new rooms with even more puzzles. Every puzzle has to be solved with only 2 abilities: Make clones, and take controll over them. In the middle of the game when the puzzles become more challenging you also use the ability to invert gravity. That makes the game one-sided. The story is only told by text-logs you can find. I think in the puzzle-plattformer genre there're much better games which are more plattformer" and have more varying puzzles."

reviewText: I often find myself rejecting platformers on the sole basis that they are platformers. Unfair, I know, but the genre has been oversaturated with endless iterations of the same ideas. Swapper does not fit that trend. I was first drawn to it because of the incredible, hand-made clay visuals. After I was drawn in by these visuals, I was hooked by the unique gameplay mechanic of creating clones to accomplish your tasks. These clones don't just do the last actions you undertook, but rather are controlled in sync with the original character (who by now is most likely a clone as well). On top of the intriguing and often challenging gameplay, the beautiful graphics, and the sparse but interesting story, the game also presents a deep philosophical question: what makes you you? In the game, you can transfer your consciousness to any of the clones you create. When you leave an area, and often during the course of a puzzle, these clones die. If you transfer into a clone and the original dies, leaving the clone to carry on your mission and ultimately your life, are you still yourself?

reviewText:
Here's an absolutely brilliant puzzle-game.

Right from the start, the game demands that you accept its insane mechanics and then asks you to make an even bigger leap to accept its logic. The result is an unshakeable sense of immersion. The atmosphere is lonesome, the soundtrack is haunting, the voice overs are spot on, and the puzzles are mind bendingly fun.

Luckily the main focus is the physics of the environment (which is completely beautiful). Some of these puzzles, however, require extremely tight solutions that may deter some players. Next to that, I think my only real complaint is the use of the maoi head is a bit dull. Why should this mysterious alien force make use of a human face? I have no answer.

I hope this immersive gem will bring you as much joy as it brought me. I'm subtracting a few points for the mood breaking elements, resulting in an A grade of 9.2/10

reviewText:
I want to make something quick about this game because it deserves everything good that it gets. Lemme get this across first that I am a shooter junky and mostly play that genre no matter how beaten to death it may be getting. In fact, I hate playing puzzle games. It goes smoothly at first, but then I just stare at the puzzle more than actually doing anything about them around the mid to end point of these games. I have ADD, so it’s hard for me to get into something that’s not going forward by at least a margin. I’m the kind of guy who liked Splinter Cell: Conviction because you could just shoot the guys rather than waiting for them to pass by.

So, did this game make me settle down and actually have some patience with a puzzle game? No. I quit the game twice and watched an LP by the pretty cool SA forum poster Niggurath. Because of that let’s play I want to actually complete this game, possibly to a whole. I feel that it deserves to be played as a lot of games like this are a phenomenon in gaming from a design and storytelling standpoint. Examples would be Silent Hill 2 and Spec Ops: The Line that are similar. These are games that make you feel alone. Maybe in different ways where in Spec Ops you are the horrid creature in the game, or Silent Hill 2 where you are alone and fighting the horrid creatures that represent you, or this game where it’s a bit of both except without fighting and without doing the terrible things. Okay, maybe one depending on a choice.

I have a high respect for these melancholy games that get the melancholy right. I’m a person who likes funny stuff that doesn’t take itself seriously. I’m kind of telling you a lot about myself huh? I wouldn’t say I’m extremely critical about a serious story either, but unless you’re really good, some comedic relief would be really nice. Now why haven’t I gotten to the gameplay and ♥♥♥♥? The actual game? I feel like writing this more as a feeling from the game thing because it’s a game with a lot of feelings. I think I got to know a bit about the people who created this work of art and would rather respect them by not putting the typical, “So, the game goes like this!”

All I’ll say is it’s puzzly, melancholy and pretty. ♥♥♥♥ that, it’s absolutely beautiful! If the game interests you; I advise that you look into it. Don’t just buy it right away. Maybe check out Totalbiscuit's video on it since it's informational and spoiler free. Then make your choice.

reviewText:
Short version: Fun game, relatively short game, very little replay value.
Highly linear gameplay and lock-out after the ending doesn't pair well with non-linear story-telling.
Steam Achievements are unrewarding.
I'm glad I played it, but also glad I got it at a much-reduced price ($2.99) when it was on sale.
Long Version: Visually and aurally the game is fantastic. Lots of complaints about bugs/controllability in the forums, but I had no issues. The price tag on the game is for all the hard work that went into the shape and feel of it.

In it's basic mechanics, The Swapper a pretty straightforward and fairly linear puzzle game. Some folks have branded it a metroidvania" title
date: but it really isn't: you gain all the skills/tools/abilities you're going to gain in the first 5 rooms
recommended: so there's never any real limitations built into the game that would impose a need to backtrack. The only thing that could impose non-linearity on gameplay is if you get irritated at a puzzle and leave it temporarily to go solve another. You'll have to get back to it eventually
hoursPlayed: and when you do you'll be bringing all the same tools to the table as before.\n\nSo
voteText: gameplay is fun and demanding the first time through
helpfulPercent: but fairly formulaic.\n\nThe storyline comes in small doses as you work through the game. A lot of reviews have praised The Swapper for raising philosophical issues about personal identity and consciousness
votesHelpful: but reviews rarely actually discuss it. I found the links to philosophy to be pretty heavy-handed. The medium here (a game) is perhaps novel
votesTotal: but the ideas in play are far from it. The guy who handled the narrative is Tom Jubert (FTL
commentsCount: and he clearly knows this: it's as if the storyline
column16: characters
column17: and dialogue were read off of a syllabus for Metaphysics of Mind 101 -- and the game cites the syllabus. Characters named "Chalmers" and "Dennett" bicker over the nature of consciousness (see David Chamers and Dan Dennett). The ship's name is the "Theseus" (see "The Ship of Theseus" problem). All this makes one wonder who the story is written for
column18: exactly. Players unfamiliar with philosophy of mind may not see the not-so-subtle references here
column19: and so won't read into the subtext that's carrying much of the weight. Players who have read the syllabus won't find it very novel.\n\nFor anyone
column20: a difficulty with the story is that it really only comes together clearly in the last 5-10 minutes of gameplay. After a lot of slow and piecemeal development
column22: and you're finally able to do what you've been trying to do for hours of play -- so you dutifully race to the abrupt ending
column23: getting heavy doses of information that alter the narrative dramatically. Then
column25: after the ending you're locked out of the game and cannot go back into it to either (a) revisit bits of the story you've collected
column26: now wisened by a deeper understanding of what's been going on or (b)  see the alternate ending  You have to start all over again. But since nothing in gameplay changes on the second run
column27: it becomes a pretty unrewarding grind.\n\nOne thing that might force you back into the game is that you've likely missed all 10 steam achievements on the first run. That's because the developers didn't provide any description of what the achievements are

column29: I must be about to complete chapter I
column30: so I'll unlock achievement "I" in a second now and go on to chapter II -- that'd make sense

reviewText: I love puzzle platformers and simply put this is one of the best I've played to date.  It's like a combination of Limbo and Braid with a twist.
