reviewText:
The Swapper has instantly become my new favourite game. The dark and lonely space atmosphere, the haunting mystery to solve, the forbodingly thought-provoking gameplay, and even the art style and music, all combine wonderfully into a seamless and immersive tapestry.

The game reminds me more than a little of Metroid, with its vast map, and ability to back-track. In this game, however, you are not *required* to back-track, but instead you are given a variety of puzzles you can solve. You have to solve them all before the end, but along the way you can pick and choose; moving to a different puzze if one is giving you a hard time. This brilliantly avoids the tendency of most puzzle games to frustrate, causing one to close the game, and sometimes never return. In The Swapper, you don't have to leave, and if you're like me, you won't want to.

** SPOILERS BELOW **

My only desire for this game is for it to be longer. As I was nearing the end of the Theseus Station plot, I was imagining an entire new stage down on the planet, where I could learn more about the Watchers and somehow interact with them. Then after that, I envisioned, a third stage; set on a rescue ship, where your decisions influence what will happen when you reach home. The real ending was fantastic, but I wanted more of the game! (compliment, not critisism)

reviewText:
I couldn't get this to run intially with my older laptops but it works fine when you set Steam/Settings/Beta/compatibility.
(Graphics Symtom- will show a loading bar and does finish, but then after this it will have a full  blank screen with a small central 50 x 50mm section where you can see the mouse curser only. The community overlay function does work (Shift tab). )
So worked on my Computer 64bit dual core processer. 4GBRAM & HD4570 card. Win7
It also tested ok on a 32bit 2core duo processor. 2GBRAM & GF8400 card. Vista
The game itself is a lot of fun, has no stressful time pressures and no violence- fine to let young kids play. The skills and tactics of cloning & moving yourself/s to solve the puzzle screen areas are learnt in a very well constructed linear way. One thing I didn't realise you meant to do to aquire achievements was to scan for secret areas - make sure you start early on that.
If you get stuck steam forums have walkthrough answers etc but generaly you will be fine working them out with patience. Enjoy

reviewText:
One of the most unique puzzle platformers I've played. Combines metroid vania esque exploration and vibes of isolation with mind bending puzzles that can get so complex you feel like a rocked scientist when you finally figure them out.

Only gripe I had is that there were some puzzles near the end where strictly speaking one could figure out the solution pretty quickly, but due to the mechanics were an absolute ♥♥♥♥♥ to actually pull off due to being split up into phases where if one phase failed to work, the entire process had to be done from scratch. Such a puzzle platformer should strike a balance between the two dichotomies, so its a shame sometimes the game leaned too far either way at times.

Also the story starts out a bit confusing but becomes more clear and intriguing once a plot foundation is set. In short, it provokes existential questions about how the mind, body and soul work and making comparisons between humanity and a new found alien 'lifeform' (If they can even be called living anyway) which fair to say is surprisingly original in execution.

Graphics wise, it's also very refreshing to see a somewhat hand made look to the models, particularly the protagonist who looks like a rigid mannequin. At first this may seem odd but it only makes the protagonist look that more fragile and defenseless, especially when seeing the protagonist and his/her clones being wasted.

The soundtrack is also really good and at times reminded me of Interstellar. There were moments I just stopped progressing to the next room because I was too distracted by the musical movements being so good, even long after I completed the puzzle of said room.

This is an otherwise short game where you spend as much time figuring out the story as the puzzles themselves and I feel that makes this game a very wholistic experience.

Highly recommended.
